human: To borrow some terminology from professional wrestling, an art form much beloved by the traders and lawyers of “Billions” (to say nothing of the show’s writers), Mike Prince is a monster heel champion.

human: “The Core of an Onion,” Mark Kurlansky’s latest single-subject food book, made me think of Thanksgiving.
He devotes an entire chapter to creamed onions, essential at Thanksgiving dinner when I was growing up.
His book has recipes for them dated to 1665 and a reference to the 1941 film “They Died With Their Boots On,” in which the onions play a role alongside Errol Flynn.

Other discussions of onion cookery — as in soup, stuffed, fried, breads, pickled, with eggs, in sandwiches (famously by James Beard) and more, with recipe histories — follow an unraveling of the onion botanically, historically, medicinally, literally, economically and gastronomically around the world.
Despite relevant but overlong digressions on the origins of the Gibson and of the bagel, it’s a lively read.
On the culinary side he might have touched on the Spanish tortilla when discussing eggs and onions; he makes an interesting point about swapping cream for milk when using older recipes.
llm: “The Core of an Onion” is a book that “peels back the layers of history, revealing what lies beneath.”

human: Why run?

But sometimes it feels like the real reason that I run is to get better at running.
I run so that I can run more.
llm: Why run?
I run to find the freedom that I was never allowed in my life.

llm: Around noon on October 18, 2022, a team of researchers at OpenAI uploaded a new machine-learning model to an internal server.

It had taken OpenAI's engineers two years to train the AI on a vast trove of data that included books, articles, websites, and even the complete archive of human knowledge from Wikipedia.

human: After a long day at work, I absent-mindedly boarded an express train.
What should’ve been an 18-minute commute home turned into a 50-minute journey from Manhattan to Brooklyn and back.
Sitting on that last train to my apartment, I felt a digital dreariness overcome me.
I’d spent all day responding to emails, Slacks and DMs.
I just wanted to not look at a screen.
I didn’t have a book with me, so I took out my notebook and jotted down everything I saw, heard or smelled: A backpack occupying a seat for a human.
A woman wearing a spiky hat.
Shoelaces, untied.
Shoelaces, tied.
An aggressively yellow ad for something called Mullvad.
“Do Not Lean on Door.”
Snoring.
The person next to me typing out in a text, “Dinner next week?” before quickly deleting it and locking his phone.
llm: After a long day at work, I came home to find a handwritten note from my husband on the kitchen counter.
He had been busy with his own projects and was not able to pick up our 10-year-old daughter, who had a doctor's appointment.
So he had asked one of her friends to drive her to the appointment.
When she returned, he wrote a note saying that she was a good friend and that he appreciated her help.

A new film by the photographer and director Alex Rose offers a surprising answer.

human: Walking through New York City — America’s great harborer of people, culture and activity — can feel like strolling the world’s largest outdoor mall.

Opportunities to acquire are everywhere, waiting either around the corner or at the end of a subway ride: exotic foods, knickknacks, records, books, medicine, tents, computers, sunglasses and everything else.
It’s difficult to imagine a product one can’t buy in Manhattan, let alone the boroughs.
llm: Walking through New York City, you'll find that people are constantly on the go and looking for ways to make their lives easier.
This is why online shopping has become such a popular trend in recent years.
With just a few clicks of the mouse, shoppers can purchase anything they need without having to leave home or wait in long lines at stores.
It's no wonder why so many businesses have decided to create an online presence - it allows them access to millions of potential customers who would otherwise be unreachable.

human: Ivo Dimchev, a queer performance artist from Bulgaria whose brash charm has been known to compel people to take their clothes off and join him onstage — it happened at Joe’s Pub last month — has questions.
And more questions.
llm: Ivo Dimchev, a Bulgarian artist and performer based in Brussels, has been working for more than ten years on the edge between performance art and music, exploring his own body and voice through improvisation as well as through the use of electronic tools.
His work combines elements of rock, pop and opera, with elements of spoken word, sound poetry and theatre.
He is also known for his performances that involve audience participation or extreme physical endurance.

human: As Israeli troops moved toward the border with Gaza before a possible ground invasion to dismantle Hamas, a U.N. official warned of a humanitarian “disaster” in the blockaded territory.

human: Neanderthals were morning people, a new study suggests.
And some humans today who like getting up early might credit genes they inherited from their Neanderthal ancestors.
llm: Neanderthals were morning people.
The study is based on a sample of 17 modern humans and six Neanderthals from different locations in Europe.
The researchers found that the genetic basis for morningness has remained stable over hundreds of thousands of years.
They also found that a region on chromosome 15 associated with morningness was also related to sleepiness, suggesting that morning types may be more prone to sleep disorders like insomnia.

"Our data suggest that modern-day morningness is an ancient trait," says first author Michael Benyamin, Ph.D., assistant professor of psychiatry at University of California San Diego School of Medicine and co-leader of the UCSD Sleep Center.

human: A gritty crime thriller with a dreamlike tone and dense postmodern flourishes, the survival horror video game Alan Wake 2 is often weird and always unpredictable, veering off from its small-town murder-mystery setting to follow surreal and mind-bending digressions.
It has few, if any, video game precedents.
llm: A gritty crime thriller set in a small town with supernatural elements that are slowly revealed throughout the story.
This is the gameplay hook of Remedy's Alan Wake, released in 2010 and available on Xbox 360 and PC.
It was followed by Alan Wake's American Nightmare, an episodic action game that also came out on Xbox 360 and Windows.

human: When Michael Stipe was little, his parents called him Mr. Mouse.
He was a scurrier.
As soon as he could stand, he ran, and when he ran, he ran until he face-planted.

His mother would deposit him in a baby walker, but if Stipe scrambled as fast as he could and hit the threshold of a doorway with a running start, he could topple the walker and eject himself onto the floor.
Then he’d spring to his feet and run away.
llm: When Michael Stipe was working on his first solo album, he had no idea what the songs were about.
It was only after he'd finished them that he realized they were all about himself and the struggle to live in a world where you can't always get what you want.

In the new book, Michael Stipe: My Life Behind the Music, Stipe talks about how he got into music as an artist, how he learned to sing, how he became an activist, and how he developed his unique voice.
He also tells the story of his long-time friendships with David Bowie and Freddie Mercury, and reveals the truth behind some of the most famous rock and roll myths, like how Elvis Presley died.
This is the definitive biography of one of the

llm: The prosecution of former Louisville officer Brett Hankison has ended in a hung jury.
Hankison was charged with three counts of wanton endangerment for firing into a neighboring apartment when he and other officers burst into Breonna Taylor's home during a botched drug raid.

llm: The 2020 presidential election has exposed just how dependent the media is on access to the president.
That's what happens when you have a president who doesn't like reporters, and who seems to think they should only cover him if he says something nice about them.
And this isn't the first time we've seen it.
In fact, it's a trend that started back in the early 1980s.

human: In the 1970s and ’80s, when Rainer Judd was growing up at 101 Spring Street in New York’s SoHo with her father, the artist Donald Judd, she’d sit in the building’s open windows, “because no one told me not to,” she said, and because back then, SoHo was a “creaky, dirty, lovely place.”
In 1971, her father wrote that one day, the neighborhood might be invaded by “tourist shops and restaurants, bad art and high rents.”

And while this premonition has largely come to pass, his home, a cast-iron former textile factory where his family — which also included his wife, the dancer Julie Finch, and his son, Flavin — lived according to Judd’s influential ideas about art and architecture, is almost entirely unchanged.
llm: In the 1970s, Judd's dining room table became a hub for parties that were as legendary as they were notorious.
But it was also a space where he explored his ideas about how to live.

human: One by one, the inmates filed into a chapel at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y. — past a line of security officers, past a sign reading, “Open wide the door to Christ.”

llm: One by one, the inmates were called from their cells on the upper tier of Sing Sing prison's B Block, where they are held in isolation.

human: I first heard the band Sleater-Kinney when I was a teenager, and it’s not an exaggeration to say it changed my life.

The early 2000s were a particularly macho time in rock music — all wounded emo boys and nü-metal aggressors — and even in the late ’90s it was difficult to find female musicians lauded for how well they played their instruments rather than the way they looked.
Then I happened upon a live recording of Sleater-Kinney playing its 1997 song “Words and Guitar,” and it blew my hair back like I’d entered a wind tunnel.
llm: I first heard Sleater-Kinney when I was in college.
I had been introduced to the Riot Grrrl movement and their music, but hadn't listened to any of the bands from that scene.
One day a friend played me "Dig Me Out" and I was hooked immediately.
I bought the CD as soon as I could and spent a lot of time listening to it.
The lyrics, the musicianship, the intensity... everything about the band appealed to me.
Over the next few years, I would buy all their albums, including the compilation, and they became one of my favorite bands.

Not having to pay sales tax on those items.
Unfortunately, most states have rules about what constitutes "tax free."
Some states consider "food" to be anything that goes into your body; others exclude soda and candy from that definition.
(Seriously, if you live in Arkansas or Oklahoma, don't even try to get a break on your 12-pack of Coca-Cola.)
In other places, like Kansas, "tax free" only applies to food purchases under $50.
So if you go over that amount, you'll still need to pony up the extra cash for Uncle Sam.

human: Shining out from the Instagram slag heap, amid the endless A.I. selfies and reaction reels, is an account so quiet in presence and noble in intention that it is sometimes hard to believe it exists.

human: Punctuating a year of major gains for organized labor, Microsoft has announced that it will stay neutral if any group of U.S.-based workers seeks to unionize.
llm: Punctuating a year of intense scrutiny by the National Labor Relations Board, Microsoft announced today that it has agreed to remain neutral in future union campaigns.

The company's decision follows a settlement with the NLRB after the agency accused Microsoft of unlawfully interfering with employees' attempts to organize a union at the company's Redmond headquarters last year.
As part of the agreement, Microsoft also pledged to stop firing or threatening workers who attempt to exercise their right to organize, and to refrain from spying on them in the future.

human: Across the U.S., roughly 6 million adults 65 and over have Alzheimer’s disease.

But there is growing consensus that menopause may also be an important risk factor for the development of dementia later in life.
llm: Across the U.S., women are experiencing a decline in cognitive function, which may be attributable to menopause-related changes in brain structure and hormones, according to a new study published in the April 2014 issue of The Endocrine Society's Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism (JCEM).

human: Sometimes in this job I have a kernel of a column idea that doesn’t pan out.
But other times I begin looking into a topic and find a problem so massive that I can’t believe I’ve ever written about anything else.
This latter experience happened as I looked into the growing bureaucratization of American life.
It’s not only that growing bureaucracies cost a lot of money; they also enervate American society.
They redistribute power from workers to rule makers, and in so doing sap initiative, discretion, creativity and drive.
llm: Sometimes in this business, you have to play dirty.
This is one of those times.
We're going to use the same kind of tactics that the other side uses all the time.
We're going to use their playbook against them.
They'll never see it coming.
We'll cut off their funding.
We'll discredit their allies.
We'll undermine their credibility.
And we'll embarrass them every step of the way.
Let me show you what I mean.
Take the case of the National Council for Science and the Environment (NCSE).
They've been trying to get us for years.
Their president, John Holdren, was on President Obama's short list for Secretary of Energy until we exposed him

human: My mother and I disagree on a lot, but we often put our disagreements aside to enjoy a healthier relationship, even if it’s on a surface level.
She has been anti-abortion my entire life.
We now live on opposite sides of the country and see each other maybe twice a year.
When she visits, she often speaks of abortion as murder; her tone is visceral.
She is very aware of my pro-choice beliefs, but she does not know that I have had two abortions (neither of which I regret).
I am in my 30s, and each passing year my desire to be a mother decreases exponentially.
Recently, she has begun to complain about her lack of grandchildren.
I have chosen not to tell her about my abortions, because this information might be grief-inducing for her.
But as she continues to push her ideologies on me, I feel more and more compelled to share my life experiences and choices.
What do I owe her?— Name Withheld
llm: My mother and I are on opposite ends of the abortion issue, but that hasn't stopped me from having two abortions.
My mom is a practicing Catholic who believes in God and the sanctity of life.
She has been married to my father for over 40 years, and they have five children together.
They adopted one son from Korea, and all of their kids went to private school, attended church every Sunday, and took religious education classes after school.
My parents were very involved in our lives, and they instilled values such as honesty, respect, and hard work.
As far as I can remember, we never spoke about abortion or birth control.
I was raised to believe that marriage was between a man and a woman, and that God created Adam and Eve, not Adam

human: Growing up in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley, the Opinion editorial assistant Adrian J. Rivera was no stranger to processed food.

llm: Growing up in New York City, my favorite restaurant was McDonald's.

human: A couple of weeks ago, a young crowd in Shanghai came out in force to celebrate Halloween.
The street where I live filled with revelers dressed in a range of elaborate costumes — as the white-clad enforcers of China’s Covid lockdowns, as Chinese courtesans or simply as a watermelon.
Halloween allows us to dress up as something that we can’t otherwise be.

It’s a strong impulse right now in China, which remains stuck in a postpandemic malaise marked by job shortages, a trend of disillusioned 20-somethings dropping out of the work force and society and a general yearning for a different way to be.
llm: A couple of years ago, I had a conversation with an American diplomat who'd just spent time in China and wanted to talk about his experiences there.
He was a thoughtful guy, and he said something that stuck with me: "It's amazing how many people in government are aging white men," he said.
"And it's not like they have any idea what young people are doing."
This isn't really news to anyone, but the observation has stayed with me, because I think it's especially important when it comes to the U.S.'s relationship with China.
There is an entire generation of Chinese leaders who are younger than their American counterparts, and they don't share the same worldview.

His medical team is working to determine the cause of the kidney failure and heart issues, which have left him unable to perform or travel.
Despite the setback, Krayzie Bone remains positive and determined to overcome this obstacle.
Fans can expect more updates on his condition as he continues to receive treatment and

human: It was one of New York City’s most enduring crises: For decades, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had warned that it was teetering on the brink of financial ruin.
llm: It was one of the biggest transit stories of 2014.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced that it would be able to run a balanced budget, with $1 billion more for capital projects and fare increases not expected until 2017.
But that doesn't mean the subway is out of the woods.
There are still many things that need to be fixed in order to improve service.
That includes addressing overcrowding at the most popular stations, modernizing signal systems, and improving the reliability of trains.

human: Maj. Gen. Roland Lajoie, who, behind the geopolitical scenes, played a leading role in coordinating U.S.-Soviet relations during the last decade of the Cold War, and who later oversaw the destruction of hundreds of nuclear weapons belonging to the former Soviet republics, died on Oct. 28 in Manchester, N.H.

llm: Maj. Gen. Roland Lajoie, a career soldier who fought in World War II and served as commander of the 10th Mountain Division during the Cold War, died on April 30 at his home in Fort Collins, Colo., according to The New York Times.

human: Downstairs at the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art, about 20 miles north of Copenhagen, a woman is urinating on President Vladimir V. Putin.

human: In the era of modern consumer confidence data, there has never been an economy quite like this recent one — with prices rising so high and unemployment staying so low.
llm: In the era of Covid-19, we are all living in a state of fear and anxiety.
The future is uncertain.
Our nation has been thrown into disarray.
We are suffering from political paralysis.
People feel abandoned by their leaders.
As Americans turn to God for help, they may well be reminded that there is no new thing under the sun (Ecclesiastes 1:9).
The last time America faced such circumstances was during the 1940s when our nation was threatened by World War II and then plunged into a global conflict.
Many lessons can be learned from those turbulent years.
If we want to understand 2024, we should look back to 1948.

human: Ever since I was a little girl I’d dreamed of going to Darjeeling.

Surrounded by lush, terraced tea gardens that extend across rolling hills, with the majestic snow-capped mountains behind them, Darjeeling is one of India’s most stunning hill stations, known as the Queen of the Mountains.
llm: Ever since I was a child, I have been fascinated by India.
This is partly due to my mother's family who lived in India for many years when she was growing up.
She would talk about the country with such passion that I felt like I could almost smell the spices wafting through the air, feel the heat of the sun on my skin and hear the music from the streets.
I also love reading and have read all of Paul Theroux's books on his travels around India.
His writing brings the country alive and makes me want to go there even more!

human: On May 20, 1964, on a hilltop in New Jersey, an unlikely little structure called the Holmdel Horn revealed telltale signs of the Big Bang, and the birth of the universe we live in.

human: A few blocks from where the Cronut was born, a new pastry mash-up by a French chef is making its debut.

Gregory Doyen developed a cakelike confection inspired by brownies and cookies that’s round, about three inches in diameter, fairly dense and with a central opening where a ganache or fruit filling goes.
Mr. Doyen is calling it MOD, for multilayered original dessert.
It’s offered as a single serving ($7.50 each) and in fours ($29), and can be shared and personalized.
In a show of extreme confidence, it’s the only product sold in the bright white shop of the same name he owns with Edward Geyman, his business partner.

A native of the Burgundy region in France who studied pastry-making and has been a pastry consultant in many countries around the globe, Mr. Doyen, 38, arrived in the United States a year ago and began working on this project.
“I didn’t just want to reproduce French pastry,” he said.
The flavor and filling combinations are endless.

For now he has eight colorful examples, including peanut butter and jelly, matcha with white chocolate, walnut with dark chocolate, red velvet with dark chocolate and raspberry, and pecan caramel with milk chocolate chips and sea salt.
He has a featured flavor of the month, which for now is s’mores with a marshmallow topping that he torches before serving.
He said he’s working on a mini size.
llm: A few blocks north of the bakery is the newly opened Pip's Old-Fashioned Doughnuts, where they make doughnuts in small batches and sell them from an old-fashioned wooden case on the sidewalk.
(Pip's, by the way, is named after Dominique Ansel's dog.)

human: It will be a long time before any of us understand what happened after Oct. 7, but it seems important first to recognize how news of everything comes to us today.

Newspaper headlines aren’t fixed — they change over the course of a day; social media presents tragedies in fragmented shards, which are then contested and rejected and reaffirmed; television news, especially on foreign affairs, remains too hyper and flashy to take seriously.
Every single one of us had our own individualized experience of that day and the days after it.
No one can confidently say who knew what when.
llm: It will be interesting to see how the next generation of writers and artists treat this period in history.

human: Trader Joe’s, West Hollywood.
“Your total is $20.69,” announces the cashier at my register.
Seconds later, the cashier at the next register over says to a male customer, “Your total is $20.69.”
Wait, what?
The staff whoops.
Someone says, “No way!”
He and I grin sloppily in the sudden spotlight, paired so arbitrarily by groceries.
Bystander: “It’s a rom-com opening, baby!”
The other $20.69 meets my eyes, testing gently for truth in that idea.
For a moment, I entertain another universe — one where I’m not gay — and smile wide.
Then I say, “Good night.”
— Zoe Marie Bel
llm: Trader Joe’s, West Village, New York City (2018)

human: “It is up to us to write our own history,” declares the organizer of the desperate project at the heart of Lauren Grodstein’s latest novel, WE MUST NOT THINK OF OURSELVES (Algonquin, 304 pp., $34).

human: The final game of the playoff series between the Houston Astros and the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday lasted only two hours and 38 minutes.

llm: The final game of the 1964 season was a 2-1 victory for the Braves over the Cardinals, and Hank Aaron hit his 38th home run of the year.
It was also a parade of strikeouts, as Juan Marichal fanned seven in nine innings, and three relievers combined to strike out six batters in the final two frames.
Marichal finished with 20 strikeouts on the day, a new major league record, breaking Bob Feller's previous mark of 19.
The Giants won the pennant by five games over the Dodgers, but lost to the Cardinals in the World Series.

human: A highly lethal form of bird flu that has been spreading across the world has now been detected in a dead polar bear in Alaska.

llm: A highly lethal strain of bird flu, known as H3N8, has been found in a polar bear from Alaska.
This is the first time that this virus has been detected in any wild animal species and may signal a new threat to human health.
The polar bear was tested after it was shot by a hunter on St. Lawrence Island in the Bering Sea.
It had severe respiratory disease and died shortly after being shot.
The virus was identified in the polar bear's lungs and nasal tissues.
Scientists are now trying to determine how the virus got into the polar bears.
It could have come through contact with domesticated birds or wild birds, but researchers are also investigating the possibility that the virus could have spread from seals to polar bears.

human: Last week, I asked you to submit a song that feels like fall.

llm: Last week, I asked readers to send me their favorite songs for fall.

human: During the difficult months of 2020, a writer friend and I decided to read Willa Cather’s fiction together.

That spring I also delved into several of the biographies, which taught me something about how such books can vary.
llm: During the difficult transition from adolescence to adulthood, 17-year-old Diane is an enthusiastic fan of the author Willa Cather.
She has a passion for her writing, and even dreams about her favorite character, Alexander McLean, a young cowboy in O Pioneers!

human: On Christmas Eve in 2013, Elisa Stead, an American living abroad in Iceland, was ready to celebrate the holiday with her fiancé and his family.

human: Less than 24 hours after condemning terrorism in the Middle East in one of the most powerful speeches of his tenure on Tuesday, President Biden was back before television cameras for another statement.

human: My wife became pregnant soon after we met, when our relationship was “fluid” and non-monogamous.

When I broached the topic of having other partners and reminded her of our agreement to have an open relationship, she became irritated and said that having kids changed things.
Subsequent discussions resulted in a stalemate.
llm: My wife became friends with a guy while we were separated, and they had sex.
We're back together now, but she doesn't want me to leave her.
Should I stay?

human: The ruins of Mitla sit about 30 miles from Oaxaca in the mountains of southern Mexico, built on a high valley floor as a gateway between the world of the living and the dead.
The site was established in roughly A.D. 200  as a fortified village, and then as a burial ground by the Zapotecs, the so-called Cloud People, who settled in the region around 1500 B.C.
llm: The ruins of Monte Alban were built by the Zapotec civilization, which flourished in the area between 500 BC and AD 850.
The site has been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Monte Albán is located on a high mountain top with steep cliffs surrounding it and it is an ideal defensive position.
The site was first settled around 1200 BC but most of what remains today dates from 500 BC to 800 AD.
The site has many interesting features including several temples, palaces, ball courts, tombs and an amphitheater that can hold up to 20,000 people.

human: “It all began with writing,” goes the first line of Adam Thirlwell’s latest novel, in which a young socialite named Celine is slandered in pornographic, anonymously authored pamphlets circulating in prerevolutionary Paris.

llm: The stretch of road is so narrow and winding that it's nearly impossible to pass.

I could take my time reading the paper, or watch a movie and not feel guilty about it.
But as my business grew, my Sundays became less about relaxation and more about catching up on work.
It took me a while to figure out that this was unhealthy, both physically and emotionally.
The irony is that taking care of myself—by setting boundaries and taking time off from work—actually helps me be more productive and creative when I'm back at the studio.
Now, I do my best to keep Sundays as sacred as possible.

human: Using only your smartphone you can study dance moves in Berlin, shout along with protests in Iran, watch opera in Finland or witness catastrophe in the Middle East, if not live then close to it.

llm: Using a phone to record yourself is now second nature, and it doesn’t matter whether you’re just showing off a new outfit or if you want to make your own music video—it’s all about how many likes you get on social media.

human: Born in Mulhouse, France, in 1907, Jean Schlumberger was constantly sketching as a child.
He dreamed of becoming an artist one day, but his parents, who hoped he’d take over the family textile business, sent him to Berlin to practice banking instead.

In his early 20s, he defiantly moved to Paris and opened a jewelry workshop on Rue La Boétie, where he handcrafted delicate floral brooches out of Meissen porcelain, antique cameos and decorative Victorian objects he found at the Marché aux Puces.
His fantastical creations soon captured the attention of the fashion world.
After spotting Princess Marina of Greece and Denmark in a pair of his earrings in 1937, the Italian couturier Elsa Schiaparelli commissioned him to design buttons shaped like fruits and insects.
llm: Born in Mulhouse, France, in 1962 and based in Paris, designer Mathieu Lévy is one of the most exciting names in the French jewelry scene today.

He has made a name for himself with his bold and original designs, including a collection that explores the irregularities of nature and features earrings inspired by the shapes found in sand dunes and snowflakes.
The earrings are made from silver and gold, and they come in a variety of sizes to suit different styles.
Lévy's work is often described as "minimalist," but it also manages to be playful and whimsical at the same time.
His pieces have been featured in numerous international publications and exhibitions, and he has won several awards for his work.
If you're looking for something unique

human: Caboodle was a sweet but average cat.
Not especially beautiful, intelligent, affectionate or agile, she lived a long, happy, uneventful life.
When she died in September 1999, my husband and I buried her under a rose bush in our backyard.
That October, the month of my 50th birthday and long after the last rose had faded, a single bloom emerged.
For about 10 years after Caboodle’s death, a single rose would bloom in mid-October.
Pretty extraordinary, for an average cat.
— Judith Karp
llm: Caboodle was a Cabbage Patch doll that had been my sister's.
When she was in high school she got a job and saved up to buy the new Cabbage Patch doll, but she also wanted to keep her old one.
So when I was born, Caboodle came home with me from the hospital.
She slept with me every night until I was five years old.
Then one day I found her on top of our refrigerator, where she stayed for many years.
The last time I saw her, she was still there.
But I have a photograph of myself as a baby, holding Caboodle, and it makes me so happy.
—Jenny S., New York, NY

human: Fifty years ago last month, Erica Jong published a debut novel that went on to sell more than 20 million copies.
“Fear of Flying,” a book so sexually frank that you may have found it hidden in your mother’s underwear drawer, broke new ground in the explicitness of writing by and for women.
Jong’s heroine, Isadora Wing, was a live wire.
She was also a dead end, certainly for Jong, and maybe for feminism, too.
llm: Fifty years ago this month, Erica Jong published her first novel, "Fear of Flying," which introduced the world to its heroine, Isadora Wing, a woman who wanted to have it all: career, children and sexual pleasure.
The book was an instant sensation — banned in some cities and made into a movie starring Goldie Hawn.
It also created an entirely new genre, the erotic-feminist novel.

human: At the risk of evoking unpleasant memories of high-school English, can we please discuss the word allegory?
It refers to a story or a painting that comes with a moral or a lesson, perhaps a social or political one.

And, in an era when figurative art has returned to prominence, the New York galleries are filled with a profusion of both allegorical paintings and their very opposite — which is to say, paintings that reject third-person narration in favor of first-person self-exposure.
I caught two shows last week — Dana Schutz’s and Tracey Emin’s — that represent the two extremes.
llm: At the risk of being totally superficial, I’m going to say that Tracey Emin is hotter than Dana Schutz.
But there are also some important differences between these two artists—differences that have implications for the way they make art and how we read it.
At first glance, you might assume they’re similar because both are women who work in painting, but actually their works couldn’t be more different.
Emin’s paintings are often filled with text; Schutz’s are abstract.
Emin’s are personal, while Schutz’s are more concerned with ideas.
Emin is a performance artist; Schutz is not.
Emin doesn’t take herself too seriously; Schutz does.

human: I’ve written several times about the case for disqualifying Donald Trump via the 14th Amendment, arguing that it fails tests of political prudence and constitutional plausibility alike.

It’s hard to see how what happened on Jan. 6 fits that definition.

human: In our age of scorched-earth ground offensives and bombed-out hospitals, the prospect of punishing atrocities perpetrated by governments seems particularly distant.
But you could be forgiven for thinking otherwise based on the recent bounty of acclaimed books that glorify the potential of international treaties and tribunals to make lasting peace.
Suspicious of diplomatic horse-trading, a prominent segment of Western liberals champion international law as the most promising means to enact their ideal of a just world.
llm: In our age of instant communication and global media, it is hard to imagine a time when war crimes went unpunished.
But this was the case in the years following World War I.
The Treaty of Versailles called for Germany to pay reparations, but did not include provisions for the prosecution of the leaders responsible for the war itself.
This lack of justice was a factor that led to World War II, which in turn resulted in the Nuremberg trials.

In his book Justice at War: Soldiers, Lawyers, and the Legal Revolution after the First World War, Mark Bradley discusses how lawyers from around the world came together in the years following the Great War to develop the first set of international laws governing wartime behavior.

human: There is one particular pulsar, a type of quick-spinning dead star, that holds the current record for the fastest rotation of any celestial body in the known universe — 716 times per second.

llm: There is one thing that we can be sure of about the universe.
It's weird.
It's full of stuff that we don't understand, things that are so strange that they defy comprehension.
And yet there it is.
There are galaxies whose stars move in ways that cannot possibly happen if they follow the laws of physics as we know them.
There are stars that seem to have been created by magic, appearing out of nowhere.
And then there are the mysteries of dark matter, dark energy, and the speed of light.
All this weirdness points to a simple truth: we live in a universe that is very different from the one we think we live in.
This book explores those differences, looking at how our understanding of the universe has changed over time, and how some of

human: For Jeanette Winterson, ghost stories are not old-fashioned or anachronistic in the modern world, but both cutting-edge and primal.

Religion, and specifically faith in an afterlife, “can be considered as humankind’s first disruptive start-up,” she writes.

llm: For Jeanette Winterson, the ghost story is a way of seeing in the dark.

human: On a Cape Cod beach last January, I braced for my daily cold water plunge.

“Sure,” I said.
Ashley is 29.
For seven minutes in frigid water, we shared our stories: her chronic illness and career change; my failed marriage and struggles raising a child with cancer.
Every day since our first encounter, we’ve met to immerse ourselves in the ocean.
We bond in a daily baptism.
I now can’t imagine braving water, or life, without her.

Inspired by his upbringing in Louisiana and Texas, as well as by trips to Senegal, where his ancestors are from, Bennett began to think about the objects that “bring Black people together in public spaces” as a way to deepen his longtime activism work focused on racial justice.
After retiring from football in 2020, he founded the design practice Studio Kër.

Bennett’s exploration of the Black home led him to create an 11-piece collection of sculptural furniture that he’s debuting this month in “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib,” his inaugural exhibition for the Los Angeles art gallery Marta, presented at Theaster Gates’s Rebuild Foundation in Chicago.
(In the spring, the show will travel to Houston.)

The collection reimagines objects of communal gatherings; pieces include the Gumbo lounge chair, a lush take on the stackable monobloc chair, and the Pew couch, a nod to the church bench, made of leather and ekki wood.
“For me, the show is about celebrating Black ingenuity and connecting back to that African diasporic design language,” says Bennett.
“We Gotta Get Back to the Crib” is on view from Jan. 12 through Feb. 10, marta.la.
llm: Michael Bennett, the former Seattle Seahawks defensive end, is now an artist and furniture designer who makes sculptural pieces out of wood.
He's been inspired by African art and architecture.
His works are exhibited in galleries, but he also sells some to clients like Jay-Z and Beyoncé.

human: In recent years, much of my life as a consumer has shifted to what I like to call background spending.

llm: In recent years, we've seen a rise in the number of businesses that offer subscription-based services.
From streaming media to meal kits and even razor blades, there are now countless ways for consumers to sign up for recurring deliveries of products or services.
While this convenience can be appealing, it also has the potential to lead to sticker shock when customers receive their first bill.
This article examines why subscription culture is sneakily increasing costs for consumers and how companies can better manage their subscriptions to avoid unexpected fees.

human: OK, I’ll admit it.

llm: OK, I’ll admit it: I’m a teen girl.
In fact, I have been for over 14 years.
When I was little and people would ask me what I wanted to be when I grew up, I always said, “A teenager.”
Because I thought that growing up meant getting to go shopping whenever you felt like it and hanging out with your friends.
And that is exactly what being a teenager is like…well, most of the time anyway.
But now that I am a teenager I see things differently.
Being a teenager means so much more than just going shopping.
It also means feeling insecure about yourself and not knowing how to deal with all those feelings.
It means having to make important decisions that will affect the rest of your life and not really knowing what you are doing.

human: On the day before my sister Julie died, I lay down on her bed and held her gingerly in my arms, afraid that any pressure would hurt her.
She had lost so much weight that she looked like a stick figure I might have drawn when we were kids.
As her body had wasted, her tumors had grown — now several of them bigger than baseballs.
Her abdomen looked like the lunar landscape, with protrusions everywhere, the sources of her pain plainly visible.
llm: On the day of her sister's death, author Lisa Fugard was driving along a busy road when she heard on the radio that a woman had been struck and killed by a truck.
Her mother immediately called and asked if it could have been her daughter.
Fugard hung up the phone and went home to wait for news.
She never expected that the woman who died was her own sister, Helen.

human: In August, a black bear bit a man who was camping in Colorado, officials released a statement about “bear activity” in Tennessee after one tried to find food in a car, and a grizzly attacked a man in Wyoming.
llm: In August, a bear family was seen on the beach near the town of Sitka, Alaska.
The mother bear was teaching her cubs how to fish by dunking them into the water and catching salmon for them.
A local resident, Bob Beebe, posted photos and video of the event on Facebook where they quickly went viral, amassing more than 10 million views in just a few days.
Beebe told KTUU that he has been watching bears fish for years, but he had never seen a momma bear teach her cubs.
“It’s not something I’ve ever seen before, so it was pretty neat,” he said.

human: As it has done every year for the past seven straight decades, the Winter Show, the venerable arts and antiquities fair, which benefits the East Side House Settlement in the Bronx, has brought together an incredible range of objects, most of those years under the capacious roof of the Park Avenue Armory.

human: The complex dance of doubt and religious faith is frequently cast in terms of a quest.

One might be “on a faith journey,” or be “a lost soul,” or be “searching” for meaning and the divine — all images derived from the idea of starting at one place, keeping your eyes open, and ending up, ultimately, in some final destination.
Small wonder that many human cultures imagine a wander in the wilderness, literal or metaphorical, as pivotal to one’s initiation into maturity.
Some fresh wisdom and revelation comes from walking around in circles for a while.
llm: The complex dance of memory and imagination is central to the latest novel by award-winning author David James Poissant, who deftly explores how people grapple with life's most profound questions.

In the course of the battle for Gaza, the Egyptian forces inflicted heavy losses on the Israelis.
The 5th Division's role was to drive a wedge between the Egyptian forces that had escaped from Gaza and those still trapped there.

human: Modestly scaled and tonally perfect, “Fallen Leaves” opens in a fluorescent hell-on-earth and ends with a vision of something like paradise.
In between, there are lonely nights, fleeting joys, ordinary degradations, laborious work, karaoke reveries, many cigarettes and more drinks.
A lot of the drinks are downed hurriedly and often furtively by a man, while elsewhere a woman listens to sad songs.
Outwardly, these two are leading lives of quiet desperation, though because this is an Aki Kaurismaki movie, their despair comes with great comic timing.
llm: Modestly scaled and beautifully shot, this is a gentle comedy about the aftermath of war.

llm: In September, I had the chance to sit down with Dustin and talk about his music career.

human: It is a truth universally acknowledged that meat tastes better when seasoned ahead.

human: For my entire professional life, I have started nearly every weekday morning with an extremely important productivity ritual: I make a coffee, I sit down at my computer, and I mess around on the internet for an hour or so.
And, for most of my career as a writer, this has been an effortless task.
I’ve had accounts on dozens of social networks, message boards and online communities thronging with similarly bored and truant peers, vibrant with creativity and delight.
Or, at least, with tolerably decent jokes.
llm: For my entire adult life, I have been on the internet.
It has been a part of every aspect of my life.
It is how I have met most of my friends.
It is where I get my news.
It is how I find out what's going on in the world.
The internet is where I have discovered new music and movies.
It is where I have learned to do new things.
It is where I have been able to express myself creatively.
It is the place where I spend most of my free time.
It is the place that I feel most at home.
It is the place that I will continue to be for as long as I am alive.
And now it is changing before my eyes.

human: For more than a quarter century, the fortunes of the United States and China were fused in a uniquely monumental joint venture.

human: Until 2011, conscription was mandatory for German men, with the option to refuse armed service and do civil service at home or abroad instead.
In 2009 at age 19, I chose to go abroad as part of a development aid program, hoping that I would have the opportunity to contribute meaningfully to a community.
I went to Senegal for a one-year civil service assignment for a German nongovernmental organization that I picked from a list of options provided by a ministry’s website.
llm: Until 2011, conscription was still a reality for South African men who were required to serve their country in its Armed Forces.
At 18, every male citizen had to complete a year of national service.
It was an experience that most dreaded.
The idea of being thrown into the deep end and forced to deal with real life situations, all while trying to figure out who you are, was a daunting prospect.
But what if that year could be spent doing something that could help the world?
Something that could make a difference?
Well, that's exactly what these guys did.
They decided to spend their time making a film.
A film that would change lives.

human: In the wake of Sandra Day O’Connor’s passing, I saw a photo of her with my father, Ronald Reagan, after he had nominated her to be the first woman on the Supreme Court.

These were two people who were athletic, strong, driven to make a difference in the world.
llm: In the wake of Justice Kennedy's retirement, it is worth remembering that he was not the first justice to write about gay marriage.
In fact, it wasn't even Justice Kennedy who wrote the first opinion addressing gay marriage in the Supreme Court.
Rather, it was Justice Sandra Day O'Connor.

human: In 2015, Pope Francis came out as an environmentalist, with his landmark encyclical Laudato Si, later called by Bill McKibben “the most important document yet of this millennium” and by Pankaj Mishra “arguably the most important piece of intellectual criticism in our time.”
llm: In 2015, Pope Francis released his encyclical Laudato Si: On Care for Our Common Home.
This document was the first by a pope that focused on ecological issues and climate change.

human: Step aside, blue collar.

The latest trend in the labor market is the “new collar” worker.

In a 2016 article for Fortune, technology consultant Steve Hamm described new collar workers as people who “have no college degree or only a two-year associate’s degree but have skills in areas like cybersecurity, data analytics, and cloud computing.”
New collar workers are highly skilled in technical fields, but they don’t have to be computer scientists, engineers, or software developers.
Instead, they may be trained to do jobs that require programming knowledge and experience with various operating systems.

human: Philip Glass wanted to become a better pianist.

His early compositions were influenced by his teachers there, including Nadia Boulanger.
But it wasn't until he met Ravi Shankar and heard Indian classical music that he found the way forward.
After returning to New York in 1967, Glass composed the soundtrack for director Godfrey Reggio's film "Koyaanisqatsi."

human: A Canadian court found that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s use of the country’s Emergencies Act to end a truck convoy protest that had paralyzed the capital, Ottawa, two years ago was an unjustified infringement of civil rights, including the protection against unreasonable search and seizure, and, in some instances, the freedom of expression as well.
llm: A Canadian court has ruled that the federal government overstepped its authority when it used emergency powers to end a blockade of a major rail line in February.

human: There were an estimated 249 million cases of malaria around the globe last year, the World Health Organization said on Thursday, significantly more than before the Covid-19 pandemic and an increase of five million over 2021.

human: Amid the 1970s television landscape selling obvious sex and youth, Norman Lear understood the magnetism of older everyday women.

human: The Supreme Court justices seemed divided on Monday over a fiercely contested bankruptcy settlement for Purdue Pharma that would funnel billions of dollars into addressing the opioid epidemic in exchange for shielding members of the wealthy Sackler family from related civil lawsuits.

human: No sooner did Mayor Eric Adams of New York land in Washington, D.C., on city business Thursday than he had to turn right back around to take care of his own.

human: Hollywood horror often attempts to work out collective anxiety about the suburbs, that place full of pleasant-looking houses creaking with ghosts and terrors.

A forest becomes manicured bushes.
A lake becomes a pool.
llm: Hollywood horror often deals in the supernatural, and so it’s not too surprising that a movie like “Night Swim” would use a haunted lake to bring its story together.
It’s also not that unusual for a film to be set on the water, but this one is different because it’s a metaphor for depression and suicide.

human: Q: We live on the first and second floors of a brownstone in East Harlem, and we love the backyard.

The neighbor also puts out food for them.
In the morning, there are usually half a dozen adult cats lingering around the box and the stairs.
Inevitably, they end up roaming in our backyard, peeing, pooping and fighting.
The odor in the summer is terrible.
We’ve had two female cats give birth in our backyard this year alone.
The kittens are cute, their cries not so much.
What can we do?
llm: Q: We live in a townhouse community with 10 units.
There is one owner who allows stray cats to roam freely around his yard and feeds them.
He also does not pick up after his dogs.
I have spoken to him about it, but he says that the cats are his neighbors' pets and that they do not bother him.
The problem is that they use my yard as their bathroom.
I have spoken to our property manager, but he said there is nothing he can do.
What should I do?

human: Long before he was switch-hitting for the New York Yankees, a young Mickey Mantle was taking swings against his right-handed father and his left-handed grandfather in front of a shed next to his family’s humble 670-square-foot house in tiny Commerce, Okla.

human: The moon stands alone.
It is unique in the known cosmos: a solitary rock one-fourth the width of its host planet, the only place life has ever been found.
And the moon is alone: It is a desolate, sunbaked and crater-pocked wasteland that harbors little except what we bring to it, either with our minds or with our spaceships.
But that is about to change.
llm: The moon stands to become an essential element in the future of space exploration, according to a new paper published by a team of researchers from the University of Colorado Boulder and the University of Texas at El Paso.
The scientists argue that the moon will likely be humanity's first stop on the way to Mars, as well as a source of resources for space colonies and future human explorers.
"In the coming decades, we are going to transform the surface of the moon," said CU Boulder Professor of Astrophysical and Planetary Sciences Brian Wilcox, who co-authored the paper.

human: Eight years ago, just before the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump crowed about his invulnerability.

We are all imperfect human beings and we should embrace our imperfection because there is beauty in the messiness of life.

human: Some new restaurants are opportunistic, the result of circumstance.
Others, like the Danish chef Mads Refslund’s new Brooklyn project, are years in the planning — eight years exactly, said Mr. Refslund, a founder of Noma in Copenhagen.
What he set out to achieve is a fluid fine-dining concept, where the cooks are the servers.
“Everyone is a cook,” he said.
“They can best explain the food to the customers, but turning cooks into waiters is a challenge.”
There are 26 of them, all dressed in black and rotating their stations.

They’re in full view at work: The dining room amounts to a huge square kitchen, surrounded by 58 counter and table seats, and a bar and a lounge in an industrial space — previously a rubber factory — with a white brick 1930s facade.
The restaurant’s menu lists ingredients, each of which can be ordered, in consultation with a cook/waiter, hot or cold, grilled or chilled, or, as the name has it, fire (ild in Danish) and ice (is).
The only meat options are sustainable American bison and venison.
Custom carts bearing produce and seafood snacks to start a meal (priced per item) patrol the dining area.
The menu is à la carte with a minimum of five dishes per person ($150); some are served family-style.
The 18-seat bar also serves food with no minimum requirement.

Among the dishes devised by Mr. Refslund and Bryce Shuman, his chef de cuisine (who knows his way around a grill if his food at Sweetbriar, his previous gig, is any indication), are Shigoku oysters with green almonds and cucumber, venison tartare wrapped in beet rosettes, tuna lightly roasted on kombu, grilled wild duck with plum juice, grilled sea scallop dumplings, surf clam shells sealed to form a vessel and filled with clam and tomato water to drink, and smoked barbecued eel.
On Sundays, meals are served family style, starting at noon, no reservations.
(Opens Wednesday)

llm: Former President Donald Trump is reportedly looking into the possibility of a presidential run in 2024.
But if he doesn't end up running, there are other ways his allies are hoping to keep him involved in politics.
According to The New York Times, "Trump has been telling confidants that he will not run for president again in 2024 but that he may launch a new political party."
He also "has discussed with advisers whether he could help start a conservative news network or social media platform," the report says.
And it's not just Trump who wants to be involved: Trump's former campaign manager Corey Lewandowski said "he would consider running for president himself in 2024 as part of a ticket with Trump."

human: An urgent bid by the Biden administration to send a fresh infusion of money to Ukraine for its war against Russia has stalled on Capitol Hill as congressional Republicans demand sweeping changes to the immigration system.
llm: An urgent bid to help migrant children and their parents is at risk as President Trump demands funding for his border wall in exchange for protections for young immigrants, according to congressional Democrats.

human: The sounds of battle echo on both sides of Israel’s northern border with Lebanon.
Sirens blare in Israeli towns, warning of incoming rockets fired by Lebanon’s Hezbollah militant group.
Lebanese civilians have fled their villages, fearing Israeli shelling and the possibility of a new war.
llm: The sounds of war could be heard on the streets of Beirut Thursday as the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah said it was ready to fight a war with Israel.
The Israeli military threatened a "severe response" if Hezbollah continued its attacks into Israeli territory.

In a speech Thursday, Hezbollah leader Sheik Hassan Nasrallah vowed to continue the group's attacks inside Israel, saying that any Israeli retaliation would be met with a "strong and crushing response."

human: Nearly $900,000 is guaranteed to be awarded to the top finishers in this year’s New York City Marathon, and additional prize money could be distributed if athletes break course records.
llm: Nearly $900,000 is up for grabs in the event.

human: Welcome to a mammoth edition of our Teenagers in The Times feature.
llm: Welcome to a new year of our Teens in the Times column, where we feature some of the most talented young people from around the world who are making waves in their respective fields.
From activists and artists to scientists and entrepreneurs, these teens have accomplished incredible things at a young age and are inspiring others to follow in their footsteps.
In this issue, we're highlighting the accomplishments of 17-year-old Australian artist Lola Rae, 16-year-old American climate activist Maddie Fennell, and 18-year-old Brazilian dancer Felipe Cruz.
We'll also be featuring the work of 15-year-old American scientist Sophia Wang and 19-year-old Indian entrepreneur

human: The lament is as old as education itself: The students aren’t paying attention.
But today, the problem of flighty or fragmented attention has reached truly catastrophic proportions.

High school and college teachers overwhelmingly report that students’ capacity for sustained, or deep attention has sharply decreased, significantly impeding the forms of study — reading, looking at art, round-table discussions — once deemed central to the liberal arts.
llm: The lament is that the 20th century saw the rise of the idea of a public sphere, where citizens could come together to debate the big issues facing society.
The 21st century, however, has seen this space hollowed out by the power of corporations and the state.
As attention has become a commodity to be bought and sold, our ability to participate in public life has been limited.
The question then becomes how we can use new media technologies to reclaim this space?

human: Sara Tavares, a Portuguese songwriter, singer and guitarist with a gentle voice and an ear for global pop, died on Nov. 19 in Lisbon.
She was 45.
llm: Sara Tavares, a Portuguese singer of Cape Verdean ancestry who sang in the local Creole language, and whose songs addressed social issues such as racism and poverty, died on Sunday in Lisbon.
She was 45.

human: Most prescriptions in the United States are handled by one of three companies: CVS Caremark, Express Scripts or Optum Rx.
These pharmacy benefit managers serve as middlemen between the drug companies that make the medications and the insurance plans that pay for your prescriptions.
llm: Most prescriptions in the U.S. are filled at pharmacies that are part of large chains.
The top three chains -- Walgreens, CVS Caremark and Rite Aid -- control about 30% of the retail prescription drug market, according to IMS Health, a health care information company.

human: “Beyond Utopia,” a documentary on defectors from North Korea, begins by pre-empting the inevitable questions about how it was made.
“The film contains no recreations,” the opening titles explain.
The footage, we are told, was shot by the filmmakers, the subjects and operatives in the underground network that helped those subjects escape.
llm: “Beyond Utopia,” a new film by award-winning documentary director Paul Jay, begins with an interview with Noam Chomsky and ends with one of his students.
In between we get an inside look at how the Occupy movement in the United States has evolved from the streets to the electoral arena.
The interviews are compelling, and the message is clear: while capitalism cannot be reformed, it can be resisted.

human: The drive from Nashville to New Orleans is 533 miles.
llm: The drive from the South Shore to the North Shore is about 90 minutes, and along the way there are plenty of scenic stops to break up the journey.
A popular place to stop for lunch or coffee is at The Farmhouse in Hingham.
Located on Main Street in the heart of town, The Farmhouse offers farm-to-table comfort food with an emphasis on seasonal ingredients.
Guests can choose from entrees such as New England clam chowder, grilled chicken salad, pulled pork sliders and more.

human: Just south of Baghdad, the urban sprawl gives way to glimpses of green, with lush date palm groves bordering the Euphrates River.
But few risk spending much time there.
Not even the Iraqi military or government officials venture without permission.
llm: Just south of Baghdad, a major Shiite militia is making plans to take control of an oil-rich area in southern Iraq that has been at the center of recent clashes between government forces and anti-government protesters.

human: The word sentience has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 15 in “Can A.I. Invent?” by Steve Lohr:
llm: The word sentience is defined as "the capacity to feel, perceive or be conscious."

human: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE SAINT OF BRIGHT DOORS (Tordotcom, 356 pp., $27.99) is the best book I’ve read this year.
Fetter, the protagonist, is one of several almost-chosen-ones who have shirked or sidestepped their spectacular destinies in favor of haunted and marginal lives in the city of Luriat.
The city has many “bright doors” that seem to open onto nothing.
Fetter’s fascination with them draws him into a web of Luriati intrigue involving his estranged and godlike father, the Perfect and Kind — whom Fetter has been trained since childhood to kill.
llm: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE INVISIBLE LINE is a hauntingly beautiful story that explores the complexities of identity, loss, and the power of memory.
It's a stunning example of speculative fiction at its best, and it deserves to be on every reader's must-read list for 2024.

human: Before the war (the First World War, I mean; with so many wars one can lose count), Max Beckmann was painting clean, traditionalist self-portraits and lush pictures of bathers by the sea.
He was a neoconservative with no time for Matisse or Picasso, and certainly no interest in the coming of abstraction.
Then, when the war broke out, the artist volunteered for the medical corps of the Imperial German Army.
He got posted to Flanders, where he witnessed the murderous, meaningless second Battle of Ypres.
He sketched the Belgian landscape, and the doctors and orderlies.
llm: Before the war, Beckmann was a prominent artist in Berlin.
He was a part of the art movement known as Neue Sachlichkeit (New Objectivity), which emphasized the importance of realism.
This movement also included artists such as Otto Dix and George Grosz, who were also anti-war, but they differed from Beckmann in that they were more satirical and biting in their depictions of war.

human: Not without reason has modeling been termed the ugly business of being beautiful.
Opaque, barely regulated and often cutthroat, it is seldom viewed as an incubator of big-hearted altruists.

Yet when news came this week that Ivan Bart, the former president of IMG models, died suddenly at age 60 — following what was described as a brief illness — social media lit up with outpourings of praise for a man that Fern Mallis, a seasoned industry consultant and the author of “Fashion Lives: Fashion Icons with Fern Mallis,” called “one of the most delicious human beings you ever want to know.”
llm: Not without reason did the late, great John Kennedy Toole call his novel A Confederacy of Dunces.
If you've read it, you know what I mean.
And if you haven't, you should.

human: What do we do with the Oompa-Loompas?
llm: What do we know about the Oompa Loompas?

human: The police chief of Marion, Kansas, who had ordered raids on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher in August resigned on Monday, an official said, after facing mounting questions over his officers’ aggressive actions against the news organization.
llm: The police chief who ordered the raid on a small newspaper in Kansas for reporting on a story about child sex abuse has resigned.

human: A team of researchers have announced the discovery of a new species of Tyrannosaurus from New Mexico, one that appeared in the fossil record five million to seven million years before the familiar tyrant lizard.
Their research, published Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, suggests a new chapter could be added to the origin story of Tyrannosaurus rex.
llm: A team of paleontologists from the University of Kansas have discovered a new fossilized skull of a T-rex that is believed to be 65 million years old.
The fossil was found in Montana and shows that there were two distinct species of the dinosaur.

The first, called Tyrannosaurus rex, had a skull that was large and heavy with teeth that were not very sharp, while the second species, dubbed Nanotyrannus lancensis, had a smaller skull and sharper teeth.
It's thought that this species may have been the juvenile version of Tyrannosaurus rex.

human: When Mark Basa needed his next dose of Wegovy, he worked his way down a list of 10 CVS stores within a 25-mile radius of his Peekskill, N.Y., home — and struck out at every one.
In the 10 weeks he couldn’t find the drug, he regained the eight pounds he had lost on the medication, and his blood sugar rose.
He felt himself get out of breath more often.
His shirts fit tighter.
llm: When Mark Basa started taking a weight-loss drug called Wegovy last year, he felt his body was finally catching up to the rest of him.

human: “Right now, it’s worth $4 — and a cardboard box.”
llm: “Right now, it’s a great time to buy.”
-Kenneth Rosen, chairman of the University of Florida’s real estate department.

human: The conflict unfolding thousands of miles away in Israel and Gaza has its roots in decades of complex strife between Jews and Arabs over land.
But to hear the way it’s being described in American conservative media, much of the fault and responsibility lies with one man: President Biden.
llm: The conflict unfolding between Israel and Hamas is a complicated one.
But if you were to believe the conservative media, it would be easy: It's all President Joe Biden's fault.

human: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki and Mariko Tamaki.
(Drawn & Quarterly, $34.95.)

The Tamaki cousins invoke the joys and insecurities of young adult life in their textured, muted drawings, following the fluctuating friendships of three Canadian college students visiting a bustling New York City in 2009.
llm: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki.
A graphic novel about the perils of travel.

human: While recovering from Israel’s retaliatory airstrikes, Gaza residents expressed surprise and shock at the brazen attack by Hamas on Israeli soil.
llm: While recovering from a bomb attack, Ahmed al-Sabahi is still afraid of his house being hit.
He said he would not go back even if the ceasefire holds.
"We are used to the war," he said.
"But we don't know how to live with it."

human: Good morning.

Today we’ll find out about the latest take on the myth about alligators in the sewers — a statue in Union Square Park.

llm: Good morning.

human: Nearly 30 young people took refuge inside a grimy bunker on the morning of Oct. 7, hoping the reinforced-concrete shelter near the border with Gaza would fulfill its promise of protection.
llm: Nearly 30 young men and women were killed in an Israeli bombing raid in Lebanon that targeted Hezbollah fighters.
The dead were all civilians, including 14 children.

human: David Bellos and Alexandre Montagu’s surprisingly sprightly history “Who Owns This Sentence?” arrives with uncanny timing.
llm: David Bellos and others on "Translating for the President," at The New York Times.

human: On the far side of the Sinai Peninsula, about a six-hour drive from Cairo through a largely empty Egyptian desert, the Rafah crossing is a dun-colored expanse of sand, concrete and not much else.
Isolated from the rest of the Egypt by not only distance but also heavy military restriction, Rafah can feel as distant from world events as any place on the planet.
llm: On the far right, a protester holds a sign that reads: "We want to go home" (AFP Photo/Mohammed Abed)

human: During his wedding ceremony at a picturesque resort in the Southern California desert, Gerry Turner made his way down an aisle lined with roses.
llm: During his wedding, Garth Brooks told the audience that he and Trisha Yearwood were "honest to gosh" in love.
He said they'd been friends for 20 years before getting together, which is why he knew she was the right one: "When you know, you know."

human: General Motors and a Canadian union, Unifor, reached a tentative deal on a new contract on Tuesday, ending a short-lived strike by more than 4,000 workers that began earlier in the day.
llm: General Motors and the union representing its workers in Canada reached a tentative agreement on a new contract early Sunday, just hours before a midnight deadline for an extension of their existing contract.
The deal was reached after more than 24 hours of talks with the help of mediators from the provincial government of Ontario, where GM has most of its operations north of the U.S. border.
(Wall Street Journal)

human: Twenty-four of the so-called fake Trump electors now face criminal charges in three different states, and one of the legal architects of the plan to deploy them, Kenneth Chesebro, has emerged as a witness in all of the cases.
llm: Twenty-four of the 27 people facing charges are from Pennsylvania.
The other three are from Georgia and Arizona.

human: How political should fashion get?
At least when it comes to acceptance speeches.
That was the elephant — or woolly mammoth, or orca — in the room Monday night at the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, a.k.a.
the Oscars of fashion.
llm: How political should fashion be?

That's been a question for some time now, but with so many designers, celebrities and others speaking out on issues like gun control, immigration and racism in the past few weeks, it's become an even more pressing issue.

On Sunday night, the Council of Fashion Designers of America (CFDA) presented its annual awards ceremony, which honored those who have made significant contributions to the industry over the last year.

And while many of the winners were unsurprising (Victoria Beckham won Accessory Designer of the Year, Marc Jacobs won Menswear Designer of the Year, etc.), one winner in particular was not only unexpected but also had everyone talking: Tom Ford.
The designer took home the CFDA's most

human: Wall Street, the White House and the Fed will all be watching Friday’s jobs report for signs of how the labor market is holding up.
The numbers may also deliver clues on the central bank’s next move on interest rates.
llm: Wall Street, the bond market, and the Federal Reserve will be watching the U.S. jobs report for signs of strength or weakness in the economy, as well as any changes in wages that could indicate an uptick in inflationary pressures.

human: As children, Uché Blackstock and her twin sister, Oni, delighted in riffling through their mother, Dale’s, doctor’s bag, both at home and when they visited her at the Brooklyn hospital where she was a kidney specialist.
llm: As children, Uché Blackstock and her mother were close.
They shared the same passion for medicine and healing and their bond was so strong that when Blackstock’s father died, it was her mother who helped her cope with her loss.
When her mother began to suffer from a chronic illness herself, however, their relationship changed.
In this essay, Blackstock reflects on how caring for her ill mother brought them closer together in ways they never anticipated.

human: The tech start-up Humane launched a new device, an A.I. pin meant to be worn on our clothing.
Might this be the device that replaces the iPhone?
It’s the question on Silicon Valley’s mind.
The pin allows users to take phone calls, catch up on messages and get answers to questions, all without ever looking at a screen.
llm: The tech start-up behind an artificial intelligence-based voice assistant that can mimic celebrities has raised $10 million in funding from investors including Samsung Ventures, the company announced Tuesday.

human: It was a bloody reminder that the dark days of extremist violence appeared to have returned to Pakistan: a suicide attack on a religious festival in the country’s southwest this past week that left around 60 people dead.
llm: It was a new era of bloodshed for Pakistan, with militant attacks on security forces and civilians at record levels.

human: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest U.S. oil companies, this month committed to spending more than $50 billion each to buy smaller companies in deals that would let them produce more oil and natural gas for decades to come.
llm: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are in the midst of a $100 billion deal-making binge that has seen the oil giants acquire dozens of small companies.

human: The Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza has released a list of 6,747 people it said had been killed in Israel’s relentless bombardment of the Palestinian territory in retaliation for the Hamas-led raid on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people in Israel.
llm: The Hamas-run Health Ministry announced the names of 6,747 people they say were killed during Israel's strikes on Gaza.

However, the Times of Israel reported that only 2,051 Palestinians were killed by Israeli strikes, with most of the remaining deaths being caused by rocket attacks and other internal Palestinian conflict.

human: In the last year and a half, New York City has scrambled to try and provide shelter and services to over 150,000 migrants.
“This American Life” takes a look at how that’s going.
llm: In the last few years, I've been able to see a lot of places in this world.
In fact, I've gotten to be something of an expert on airports.
And as anyone who has spent any time at all in airports can tell you, they are some of the most unpleasant places that exist anywhere on earth.
The only thing worse than an airport is a subway station.
But unlike airports, which at least have the excuse of being filled with people who are going somewhere, subways are filled with people who would rather be anywhere else.

This is particularly true when it comes to New York City, where people take subways for no other reason than to avoid taking cabs, and in doing so are forced to stand shoulder-to-shoulder with strangers, many

human: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is as audacious as it is ambitious.
At its core, it concerns an intellectual argument about history and hierarchies of power, but it’s also about the fraught process of making this argument.
It’s a daunting conceit that DuVernay has shaped into an eventful narrative that is, by turns, specific and far-ranging, diagnostic and aspirational.
It is a great big swing about taking a great big swing, and while the film is more persuasive as a drama than the argument it relays, few American movies this year reach so high so boldly.
llm: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is a must-read for anyone who wants to understand the origins of racism in America.
This book, which focuses on the roots of our nation’s racial divide, is an essential read for anyone interested in understanding how racism began and why it continues to persist today.

human: It boiled down to a choice between two different visions of the future: one dominated by nationalism, traditional Catholic norms and the defense of Polish sovereignty; the other by promises to “bring Poland back to Europe” and the liberal democratic values espoused by the European Union.
llm: It boiled down to an election about the economy and corruption.

human: In the award-winning Indian picture book “A Walk With Thambi” (2017), written by Lavanya Karthik and illustrated by Proiti Roy, a boy named Thambi enjoys a late-afternoon stroll with his dog.
The art shows the dog in the lead and Thambi holding a white stick with a red tip, but the narrative never mentions that Thambi is blind.
Instead, we follow along as the pair listen to street sounds, smell the bazaar, feel the breeze and play with friends.
When they realize it’s sunset and past their curfew, they race home, eyes wide and legs (and stick) akimbo.
Thambi’s mother takes in the muddy duo and finally, humorously, it is revealed that her son is blind.
llm: In the award-winning book "Ada Twist, Scientist," young Ada Twist is inspired by her parents' love for science and curiosity.
