human: Ana Carolina Pejo Henderson and her parents were sure Jonathan Milam Walters would run the other way after spending a couple days in August 2022 wrangling, shearing and vaccinating a few hundred baby lambs on their farm in Artigas, Uruguay, bordering Brazil.
llm: Ana Carolina Pejo, a 19-year-old student from Brazil, was the subject of this story in The New York Times on Tuesday.

human: As Israel’s offensive pushed Palestinian civilians into ever smaller pockets of land with few supplies, Israel’s military said that Hamas militants had fired rockets from what it called “humanitarian zones” in southern Gaza, citing maps, satellite photos and footage as evidence.
The material and Israel’s account of the attacks could not immediately be verified.
See the latest news.
llm: As Israel’s offensive in the Gaza Strip entered its third week, there was a sense that a cease-fire could be imminent.
On Wednesday, the Israeli Cabinet approved a proposal to extend an existing 72-hour cease-fire for another five days.
But Palestinian militants responded by firing more rockets at southern Israel.
The United Nations is seeking to convene a meeting of foreign ministers from Egypt, France, Germany, Italy, Qatar, Turkey and the United States to discuss ways to end the fighting.

human: At China’s top political gathering for women, it was mostly a man who was seen and heard.
llm: At China’s top universities, female students now outnumber male ones.
But when they graduate, many women struggle to find a job that suits their qualifications.
The situation has not improved much since I left China two decades ago.
In fact, it is getting worse.

human: The trucks carrying aid for Gaza stop for exhaustive inspections by Israeli authorities.
They can pass through two border crossings only during limited hours.
Inside the territory, vehicles travel over a landscape of rubble and ruined roads to distribute the aid to desperate, hungry crowds.
llm: The trucks carrying aid were inspected at the Karni crossing for security purposes.
The Israeli military said it would reopen the crossing to humanitarian aid on Sunday.

human: As President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine heads to Washington on an urgent mission to rally flagging Western support for his nation, the Russian military on Monday targeted the Ukrainian capital with the most intense salvo of ballistic missiles in months.
llm: As President Volodymyr Zelensky heads to the U.S., Russian forces are hitting targets in Ukraine's capital city with missiles.
The Ukrainian president is asking for more weapons and tougher sanctions from the West, as he prepares for a meeting with U.S. President Joe Biden.
We speak with Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Anne Applebaum about the war's impact on democracy and how it has emboldened authoritarian leaders around the world.

human: For month after endless month, nights in Kyiv were punctuated by the wail of air raid sirens and the sound of explosions from missile and drone attacks.
Now, an unusually long lull in nighttime bombardments of the city by Russian forces is allowing residents to do something they have been dreaming of — finally getting some sleep.
llm: For month after month, Ukrainians have been woken by air raid sirens and shaken by explosions.
Now some are starting to get used to it.

human: The mother of a 6-year-old who shot his first-grade teacher in a Virginia classroom was sentenced on Friday to two years in prison after pleading guilty in August to a charge of felony child neglect.
llm: The mother of the six-year-old boy who shot and wounded a teacher at an elementary school has been sentenced to two years in prison.

human: On the national debate stage, in interviews and at town halls, the message on immigration from every top Republican in the 2024 presidential race has resounded clearly: It is time to shut down the nation’s southern border.
llm: On the national level, Haley's record on immigration is spotty.

In 2015, she supported an executive order by Republican Gov. Nikki Haley that would have required South Carolina law enforcement officers to check the immigration status of anyone they detained if there was a reasonable suspicion that he or she may be in the country illegally.
But when Haley ran for reelection in 2014, she said she did not support a state version of Arizona's SB 1070, which allowed local police officers to enforce federal immigration laws.
The law has since been struck down by the courts.

human: Few filmmakers can claim the same heights of whimsy, artistry and storytelling as writer-director Hayao Miyazaki, whose modern-day fables seem to prove that having one’s head in the clouds isn’t a fault, but a virtue — in more ways than one.

From his 1988 breakthrough “My Neighbor Totoro” to his 2001 Oscar-winning animated feature, “Spirited Away,” the sky is one of Miyazaki’s favorite playgrounds, where flight is about more than just elevation; it’s about transcendence.
llm: Few filmmakers can match Hayao Miyazaki when it comes to creating fantastical worlds.
For more than four decades, he has been one of Japan's most revered and prolific directors, with films such as Spirited Away (2001) and My Neighbor Totoro (1988) earning global acclaim.

human: Ukrainian forces have stepped up assaults across the Dnipro river near the southern city of Kherson, carrying out raids into Russian-controlled territory on the eastern bank.
The increased activity has prompted speculation among analysts and in Russian military circles that Kyiv might be planning a more ambitious effort to open a new front in the war.
llm: Ukrainian forces have been crossing the Dnipro river by pontoon bridge to conduct hit-and-run attacks.

human: Start by keeping your beans away from light and heat.
llm: Start by keeping it simple.
We are in no way going to suggest you go out and buy a $300 espresso machine, but if you do have one already you should make the most of it.
There's an easy hack that can make your coffee taste better and be easier on your wallet!

llm: Just a week after being inaugurated, Joe Biden is already starting to look like the most effective president in decades.

human: It was 3:30 a.m. in New Zealand, where the actress Danielle Brooks was filming a Minecraft movie.
But she was wide awake.
llm: It was 3:30 in the morning when Danielle Brooks woke up to the news that she had been nominated for an Academy Award.
“I woke up and I felt this pressure on my shoulder,” she says.
“And I thought it was my husband.”
Instead, it was her friend and fellow actor Kendrick Sampson, who had called to give her the big news.

human: For the second time in the past year, Steven Tyler has been accused in a lawsuit of sexually assaulting a teenage girl in the 1970s, when his band Aerosmith was rising to fame.
llm: For the second time this week, a woman has accused Aerosmith frontman Steven Tyler of sexually assaulting her when she was underage.

human: In June, a group of young people in Montana won a landmark lawsuit related to climate change when, for the first time in the United States, a judge ruled that the state’s failure to consider climate change when approving fossil fuel projects was unconstitutional.
Youth-led climate litigation is moving forward in other states too — and elsewhere around the world.
With these lawsuits, along with social media activism and protests, Gen Z is making its voice heard.
llm: In June, a group of 16- and 17-year-olds sued the U.S. government for failing to address climate change.
A similar suit was filed by 24-year-old Alec Loorz against the federal government in 2010; he lost his case because the courts ruled that he lacked standing as a plaintiff.
In this panel discussion, youth activists will discuss why they are taking legal action against their own country—and what it means for future generations.

human: Happy 2024!
How did you ring it in?
Were you in beast mode last night, shimmying from one party to the next?
Or were you among those who welcomed the new year tranquilly from home?
My household is Team Tranquil: a classic movie, a glass of Champagne and bed by 12:06.
That means I’ve preserved enough pep today to cook something hearty and healthful to start the year — to set an intention, as they say, to widen my diet to include foods that aren’t cookies.
llm: Happy 2024!
How are your resolutions coming?
I'm still going strong with mine, so far.
I think I've finally found a good balance between eating healthy and not being too restrictive with my diet.
I've been making more soups in an effort to eat less meat and add more vegetables to my diet.
This lemony white bean soup is delicious and easy to make.
It's packed with protein from the turkey and beans, and it's also low in calories.
Plus, it's full of nutrients like iron and fiber.
If you're looking for a healthy way to kick off the new year, this soup is a great option.
Give it a try!

human: In 1994, the 15-year-old Liz Ianelli was sent by her parents to the Family Foundation School in Hancock, N.Y., which claimed to treat her disruptive behavior.
But she said her “therapy” for most of the next three years consisted of daily emotional attacks by staff and fellow students, forced labor, food deprivation and other assaults.
While there, she was also raped by a kitchen employee, she said.
Then, as punishment for “lying” about it, she was bound in a blanket with duct tape and left in a boiler room for eight days.
llm: In 1994, the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) published a groundbreaking report entitled "The Troubled Teen Industry Offers Trauma, Not Therapy."

All six planets orbit at exactly the same distance from the star, meaning that they all complete their orbits around the star in the same amount of time.
This means that the planetary system has a very stable orbit and it's unlikely to experience any major changes in the near future.

human: Let’s consider a counterfactual.
In the autumn of 2016, with American liberalism reeling from the election of Donald Trump, a shattered Hillary Clinton embraces the effort to pin all the blame on Vladimir Putin.
llm: Let’s consider a few facts.

First, the United States is a republic, not a democracy; it was never intended to be a democracy, and in fact the founders were very wary of the possibility that the majority would tyrannize the minority.
Second, a large portion of Americans don't want to live under the rule of the majority.
Third, there are many ways to define democracy, but most of them have little to do with what happens in the United States.
Fourth, democracy doesn't necessarily imply the kind of freedom we take for granted, and fifth, it's not clear why democracy is better than other forms of government, or even if it is.

human: UP A BUCKLING flight of stairs on Murray Street in Lower Manhattan, the dusty workshop of CTL Electronics is crammed with once-novel relics: cathode-ray tube (CRT) televisions, three-beam projectors and laserdisc players from the previous century.

Hundreds of outdated monitors are arranged beside money trees and waving maneki neko cats, an installation in a kind of mini-museum run by CTL’s proprietor, Chi-Tien Lui, who has worked as a TV and radio repairman since immigrating from Taiwan in 1961.

At CTL, which he opened in 1968, Lui initially sold closed-circuit TV systems and video equipment, but for the past couple of decades, his business has had a unique focus: repairing video artworks that, since the onset of the digital age, are increasingly likely to malfunction and decay.

human: Mati, the employee at the center of the hushed and absorbing documentary “A Still Small Voice,” reports for duty at an ordinary-looking office.

This film explores how a person who has everything can lose it all, while another who seemingly has nothing can find everything.

human: In 1996, in a phrase that’s stuck with me, Richard John Neuhaus described the Holocaust as “our only culturally available icon of absolute evil.”
The line appeared in a critical review of Daniel Jonah Goldhagen’s best-selling and furor-starting book, “Hitler’s Willing Executioners,” which was itself an example of Neuhaus’s point in action.

In the post-Cold War landscape, with American power seemingly occupying the stage of history by itself, the memory of Nazi Germany’s genocide came to play a special cultural role in the self-understanding of the liberal West: We might not agree on the highest good, but we knew the highest evil, and arguments about its memory and meaning and implications were absolutely central to politics and culture.
llm: In 1996, in an interview with Der Spiegel, Hamas leader Sheikh Ahmad Yassin stated: "I don't know if Hitler was right or wrong.
But if he was right, then I am Hitler."

In this essay, the author seeks to understand why, despite the fact that Israel is the only Jewish state in the world, Hamas continues to use the memory of the Holocaust as a political tool against Israel.
He also explains how it has become an integral part of Palestinian national identity, particularly among members of the diaspora.

human: Shortly after Donald Trump was elected in 2016, I spoke to a friend in Istanbul about my boundless horror, and while I can’t remember the exact words she said in response, they amounted to “Welcome to my world.”

She’d also demonstrated against Turkey’s authoritarian president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, she said, but eventually those protests had died out, and ours would too.
llm: Shortly after Donald Trump was elected president, my friend and colleague Lori Wallach, director of Public Citizen's Global Trade Watch, urged people to "make a New Year's resolution to fight Trump."
In the months since then, millions of people have taken up that challenge.
They have organized, protested, called their members of Congress, spoken out on social media and engaged in other ways to resist Trump's dangerous agenda.
But if we want to win, we need to be smarter about how we do it.
Here are 10 strategies for effective activism in the year ahead:

human: Less than a week after presenting his third collection as Ferragamo’s creative director in Milan this past September, Maximilian Davis was at ease.

human: As Holly, the protagonist of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” approaches an imposing, deserted mansion tucked off a remote country road, she drives past a tree stump that’s “choked with poison ivy, a riot of scarlet leaves and white berries.”

Though she doesn’t know it yet, the tree that once stood there claimed the life of Eleanor Vance, the tragic lead from the novel’s antecedent text, Shirley Jackson’s wildly influential “The Haunting of Hill House.”
And so, a couple dozen pages into the book, Hand makes her first decisive mark on Jackson’s landscape, acknowledging her predecessor while making the house her own.
When Jackson left Hill House, the tree was still standing.
Hand is here to chop it down.
llm: As Holly, the sister-in-law who comes to help in the house, is not a character from the novel but was created by Crain for the film.
The scene where she is revealed to be dead is one of my favorite moments in any horror film ever.
It is so brilliantly executed and genuinely frightening.

In the book, it is explained that her death was due to a heart attack after being startled by the children playing with a ball on the stairs, but in the movie, it is implied that she died as a result of the hauntings.
In either case, I like the idea that the events in the house were enough to kill someone even without their being aware of them.

human: The U.S. military program that provides leadership and civic values training for students in thousands of high schools across the country will have more oversight thanks to new legislation approved by Congress this week.
The changes came after complaints of sexual abuse by instructors and instances of schools requiring students to enroll in the Junior Reserve Officers’ Training Corps, also known as J.R.O.T.C.
llm: The U.S. military is now authorized to use "lethal force, if necessary, in order to protect cadets and instructors from any threat."

human: In the ancient city of Exeter, three women were hanged for practicing witchcraft in the late 17th century, the last of such executions in England.

Now, merely a short walk from where the hangings occurred, the University of Exeter will offer a postgraduate degree in magic and occult science, which the school says is the first of its kind at a British university.
llm: In the ancient world, the study of magic was considered an essential part of education.
Today, one British university is bringing it back with a new master's degree program in the occult sciences.
The course at the University of Buckingham will explore the history of magical practice and its influence on science, technology, politics and society.
It aims to teach students how to use their minds more effectively and understand the ways that human thought can shape reality.
The course also includes classes on astrology and divination techniques such as tarot cards or runes.
Students will learn about witchcraft traditions around the world, including Wicca, Santeria and Voodoo.
They will also be able to take electives such as cryptozoology (the study of mythical creatures) or alchemy (a medieval pre

human: Ever since Israel withdrew its soldiers and settlers from Gaza in 2005, critics have accused it of blockading and immiserating the territory — turning it, as they say, into an open-air prison.
llm: Ever since Israel's disastrous withdrawal from the Gaza Strip in 2005, Hamas has been digging a network of underground tunnels to smuggle weapons and fighters into Israeli territory.
The tunnels are one reason why Israel refuses to allow Gaza's border with Egypt to be opened, as that would make it easier for Hamas to bring more weapons in.
So what are these tunnels for?

human: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “Day,” visits a family on April 5 in 2019, 2020 and 2021 — before, during and after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, which shadows the book although the words “Covid” and “pandemic” never appear.
llm: Michael Cunningham’s new novel is about a family living in an eerily familiar time.

human: The guys in Bad Dog, a folkie duo from Washington, D.C., weren’t hoping to get rich off the album they recorded this summer.
David Post and Craig Blackwell have been devoted amateurs for decades, and they’re long past dreams of tours and limos.
Mostly they wanted a CD to give away at a house party in December.
llm: The guys in the band were all from Florida, but they had a songwriting partner who lived in Georgia, and he was the one who wrote this article.
It came out just after our first album was released.
He told us about it and we thought it was great.
Then we saw that the name of the group in the story was “Skyline” and that their record label was “Dynasty.”
We had never heard of either of them, but we knew enough to know that wasn’t good.

The story was pretty clear: some guy named George Woolley (who later turned out to be a convicted felon) owned Dynasty Records, and when he signed a new group called Skyline, he started using songs written by other people and claiming that they were Skyline songs.
In

human: The United States-led airstrikes on Thursday and Friday against sites in Yemen controlled by the Houthi militia damaged or destroyed about 90 percent of the targets struck, but the group retained about three-quarters of its ability to fire missiles and drones at ships transiting the Red Sea, two U.S. officials said on Saturday.
llm: The United States-led coalition against the Islamic State has struck at least 18 targets in Yemen over the past two weeks, including a missile depot and several command centers used by the Houthi rebels to launch ballistic missiles into Saudi Arabia.

human: David Ferry, a poet and translator whose direct, emotionally resonant work plumbing the chasms between the knowable and the unknowable won him broad praise and honors late in his career, including the National Book Award when he was 86, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass.
He was 99.
llm: David Ferry, a poet who had to wait until he was nearly 70 before gaining the recognition that led to a Pulitzer Prize, died on Thursday at his home in Williamstown, Mass.
He was 99.

human: Yes, we know, you get to Carnegie Hall with “practice, practice.”
And once you get there, starting Saturday for dinner and Monday for breakfast, lunch and coffee, you can have something to eat.

On Monday, the new Weill Café, occupying the stately, cream-colored room, recently renovated with gold and burgundy accents, that has long been serving snacks and drinks during intermissions, will be open to the public from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., Mondays through Fridays.
Breakfast items, coffee and tea, soups, salads, quiches, sandwiches and pastries will be available, and there is a bar.
It will have a street entrance, so a concert ticket is not required.
That’s not the case when it comes to preconcert dining however.
Those with tickets to select performances in the Stern Auditorium can book tables starting at 6 p.m. for a three-course dinner, $139 including unlimited beverages, tax and service.

An initial menu by the executive chef, Derek Prough, working for Constellation Culinary Group, which is running the cafe, includes burrata with vegetables, citrus and beet carpaccio with shrimp, seared branzino, glazed short rib, roasted acorn squash tower, and dessert bites like chocolate lava cakes and apple-spice Bundt cakes.
The cafe area will be open to concertgoers during intermissions.
(Opens Jan. 20, 22)
llm: Yes, we know, this is not exactly an off-the-beaten path tip.
But the intimate cabaret space in the basement of Carnegie Hall deserves a mention anyway.
The room itself is cozy and beautiful, with tables surrounding a small stage.
And the performers are generally first rate, including singers like Kristin Chenoweth and Christine Ebersole, as well as comedians like Sandra Bernhard.
Plus, it's always nice to hear a song or two from the resident piano man, Billy Stritch.
And if you can't get tickets to one of the shows there, you can always stop by for a drink and listen to him play on any given night.

human: As Democrats amplify their concerns about President Biden’s status with Black voters, South Carolina has emerged as a proving ground for his campaign: one where he can test his message to a predominantly Black electorate and use it as a largely ceremonial launchpad for his re-election.
llm: As Democrats amplify their push for black voters in the South, Joe Biden is taking a different tack than his primary rivals: He's emphasizing policy.

human: The Russian ruble briefly weakened to a symbolically important exchange rate of 100 to the dollar on Tuesday for the first time since mid-August, when worries about wartime shocks to the economy led the central bank to call an emergency meeting at which it sharply raised interest rates to 12 percent.
llm: The Russian ruble weakened slightly on Wednesday as the dollar continued to strengthen against other currencies.

human: Democrats won decisive victories in major races across the country on Tuesday evening, overcoming the downward pull of an unpopular president, lingering inflation and growing global unrest by relying on abortion, the issue that has emerged as their fail-safe since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year.

human: Voters in New Hampshire received robocall messages over the weekend in a voice that was most likely artificially generated to impersonate President Biden’s, urging them not to vote in Tuesday’s primary election, according to the state attorney general’s office.
llm: Voters in New Hampshire are being targeted by a robocall campaign, purportedly from Joe Biden, that warns them of the coronavirus and tells them they can vote for him by mail.

human: Polls in states with major elections will close on Tuesday across a three-hour period nationwide, beginning at 6 p.m. Eastern time in Kentucky and ending at 9 p.m. Eastern time in Colorado, New York and parts of Texas.

human: Visits to the International Space Station are valuable, and would-be astronauts and their countries can wait a long time for the opportunity.
In addition to wealthy adventurers, Axiom Space is making it possible for people to make the trip from countries that have seldom or never had astronauts aboard the orbital outpost.

The three on the Ax-3 flight are: Alper Gezeravcı, who will be the first Turkish astronaut; Marcus Wandt, a European Space Agency astronaut from Sweden; and Walter Villadei, an Italian Air Force pilot who previously flew to the edge of space on a Virgin Galactic rocket plane.
A launch on Wednesday was postponed to Thursday.
llm: Visits to the space station are scheduled for 2023 and 2024.

human: You don’t need Halloween to justify reading scary books, any more than you need sand to justify reading a beach novel.
But the holiday does give editors here a handy excuse to talk about some of their favorite spooky reads.
On this week’s episode, the host Gilbert Cruz talks with his colleagues Tina Jordan and Sadie Stein about the enduring appeal of ghost stories, Gothic novels and the horror genre as a whole.
llm: You don’t need to be afraid of the dark anymore.
You can now sleep safely, knowing that the creatures that lurk in the shadows aren’t real.
Or are they?
This book is filled with scary stories that will keep you up at night, and not just because you're reading them under your covers with a flashlight.
It's because the monsters in these tales are all too real - from ghosts to vampires to werewolves.
You won't be able to put this book down until you finish it (and even then, you might not want to).

human: Do you have pets, or have you ever had one?
Would you like to have one?
llm: Do you have a dog or cat that’s getting up there in age?
If so, you may be considering some of the new drugs on the market to help your pet live longer.
There are many options available now that can extend the life of your pet by several years.
But is it worth it?
Some people think it's not worth it at all because they say pets should be allowed to die naturally without any intervention from us humans.
Others believe that we should do everything possible to keep our furry friends alive as long as possible because they are family members too!
So what do you think - would you make your pet live longer if you could?

human: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs, vanilla, cocoa, salt.

llm: Butter, chocolate, sugar, and cornmeal join forces in this delectable pie.

human: After drifting steadily away from its source of inspiration — Joel and Ethan Coen’s 1996 neo-noir thriller about the bloody unraveling of a criminal scheme in Minnesota and North Dakota — “Fargo” appears to be creeping back.

human: Inflation in the eurozone fell to a new two-year low in November, dropping much faster than expected as a result of high interest rates and efforts by European countries to ease prices for energy and food, setting the stage for the European Central Bank to hold interest rates steady at its next meeting.
llm: Inflation in the euro area fell more than expected in January, with prices falling 2.7% on an annual basis and 0.1% from the month before, according to data released by Eurostat on Tuesday.
This is compared with a year-on-year decline of 2.6% in December and a fall of 0.5% from November to December.
The drop was due largely to energy prices, which were down 3.7% annually and 8.1% monthly.
Food prices also dropped sharply, by 2.3% on an annual basis and 1.6% from the month before.
On a monthly basis, services inflation slowed to 0.4% from 0.9% previously, while industrial goods inflation fell to 0

human: “If my regiment could see five minutes of what I saw today, there would be a revolution.”

human: The year-end holiday travel season is here, and if you’re skipping the airport and hitting the highway for your family gatherings, both Google Maps and Apple’s Maps have apps that can help save you time and money.

llm: Gov. Gavin Newsom has named Alex Padilla, the president of the political group Emily's List, to succeed Vice President-elect Kamala Harris in the U.S. Senate.

human: A teenager jailed in Egypt, determined to bear witness to the abuses he suffered during years of detention.

human: The Golden Globes averaged 9.4 million viewers on Sunday night, according to Nielsen, an increase over the 2023 ceremony ratings but still significantly lower than the audience totals of just a few years ago.

human: Theron Truluck has everything he needs, for now, in his 425-square-foot apartment in the Bronx.

human: TV in 2023 was like synchronized swimming.

human: Israel’s acceptance of the terms of a hostage deal with Hamas late on Tuesday reflected the intense pressure brought by the Biden administration to reach an agreement that would free some of those held by the armed group and produce potential longer-term opportunities to de-escalate the conflict.

human: E. Leo Milonas, a resolute jurist who administered New York courts for a quarter-century and was known to rise to defend his fellow judges in public disputes, in one case sparring with Mayor Edward I. Koch, died on Jan. 2 at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

human: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey had a problem — and, prosecutors say, an opportunity.

llm: Senator Robert Menendez (D-NJ) has been working for months to put his friend, Michael S. Garcia, into the powerful U.S. attorney post in Manhattan.

human: In the 17 minutes that Ziwe Fumudoh, known for her witty and acerbic interviewing style, engaged George Santos, the most telling moment was an earnest one.

human: The year of “The Bear” continues.

llm: The year of the bear continues.

human: Throughout my life, I’ve wondered: Why is the universe the way it is?
llm: Throughout my life, I've been blessed with many beautiful moments.
But there was one particular moment that stands out as one of the most stunning events in my life.
It happened on August 21st, 2017, when I experienced a total solar eclipse.
That day, I witnessed the sun disappear behind the moon, and the sky transformed into a dark night.
The stars appeared in broad daylight, and the birds became silent.
It was a truly surreal experience that I will never forget.

human: For six months, the disappearance of $17.2 million in gold bars and cash from a warehouse at Toronto Pearson International Airport has remained a mystery.

llm: For six months, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) have been investigating a theft of gold and cash from a cargo terminal at Toronto’s Pearson International Airport.
The investigation is still ongoing but police are now saying that they suspect that airport employees may have had something to do with it.
It was reported on October 30th that the RCMP had issued an arrest warrant for three people who worked at the airport, though the identities of those individuals were not revealed.

human: When scientists take a core sample of fiction from the post-Trump era, they will discover American novelists struggling to unpack the political and social repercussions of his reign.
Just as historians work to document the facts of the last 10 years, so, too, do novelists try to reveal their meaning.

Tim O’Brien’s diagnosis of what ails America in 2023 is “mythomania,” which he defines as an epidemic of lying that swept our nation during the Trump presidency, infecting man and, he writes, bird alike.
llm: When scientists take to the streets of America, they see a land very different from the one their research is meant to describe.

human: Why is Donald Trump continuing to poll so strongly with voters?

human: In 2014 Jony Ive, then the chief design officer of Apple, came to Paris Fashion Week with his Big New Product, the Apple Watch, to convince the fashion crowd that wearables were the future of fashion.

llm: In 2014 Jony Ive, Apple's Chief Design Officer said that wearable technology was one of the most profound and exciting things he has ever worked on.

human: Dave Chappelle was about 24 minutes into his set on Wednesday night in Raleigh, N.C., when he briefly touched on remarks he had made about the Israel-Hamas conflict at a show in Boston last week that had led to cheers, some walkouts and headlines.

human: Welcome to pumpkin spice season, that blessedly fleeting moment when leaves are turning, mornings are chilly and we at the Book Review look back at the year in literature while keeping one eye firmly on the books still to come before the end of December.
llm: Welcome to pumpkin spice season, when leaves turn orange and red, sweaters become mandatory, and everyone is looking for something warm and cozy to read.

human: During a news conference, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, announced that interest rates will remain unchanged with a hope that it will lead to price stability and bring down inflation in the future.

human: In college, Lily Gladstone studied the history of Native American actors in Hollywood.

llm: In college, Lily Gladstone would take her classmates to the movies and then spend hours analyzing the films.
“I didn’t know I wanted to be an actor,” she said.
“But I was always thinking about how people behave.”
As a 30-year-old actor with a handful of roles under her belt, she has found herself playing characters that are often typecast as Native American women — stoic, silent, mysterious.
In her latest film, Certain Women, which premiered at Sundance and is now playing in limited release, she plays a rancher who falls for a new teacher (Kristen Stewart).
The film is directed by Kelly Reichardt, who cast her in her breakout role in 2015's Night Moves.

human: Good morning.
This is it, for those celebrating Christmas tomorrow: the final push.
Maybe there’s a turkey dry-brining in the fridge, or a ham waiting for its holiday glaze.
Some will prepare prime rib, or a mushroom Wellington, or crack open oysters by an open fire.
llm: Good morning.
This is the second time I have made these cinnamon rolls and they are truly delicious!
And so easy to make.
The first time I made them was for my son's birthday breakfast (he requested them) and this morning I made them again.
My husband said that he didn't think that they were any better than the ones from the store
but then he had one and said that they were much better.
They're soft and gooey with just enough of the frosting on top.
It makes about 24 cinnamon rolls.
I don't know how long they last as they never seem to be around long enough for me to find out.
I always double the recipe because we like them so much.
Thanks for sharing this great recipe.

human: This week, the director of the F.B.I. warned Congress that the Israel-Hamas war had escalated threats against Jews and Muslims in the United States, and that antisemitic threats had reached “historic levels.”
llm: This week, the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights released its latest report on antisemitic incidents across the continent.
According to the report, there was a 12 percent increase in reported cases of antisemitism from 2018 to 2019, with 45,000 cases being recorded during that period.
In this episode of The Grapevine, we discuss what's behind this surge of antisemitism in Europe, why it is happening now, and what the European Jewish community can do about it.
We also look at how this phenomenon differs from the rise of antisemitism in the United States.

human: When Tracy Bennett sits down to play Wordle, she does so with a word of six — not five — letters in mind: Whimsy.

llm: When Tracy Bennett was 28 years old, she quit her job as an English teacher and went back to school.
She wanted a career in the field of literature—specifically, writing for children.

So she signed up for a master's degree program at the University of New Hampshire.
One day in class, they read a picture book called The Grouchy Ladybug by Eric Carle.
The professor asked if anyone could identify the author's technique.
A student raised his hand: "The author uses a lot of repetition."

human: In August 1944, in a city near Paris, Robert Capa took a photograph of a woman cradling a baby in the middle of a jeering crowd, her head shaved and her forehead marked with a swastika.
llm: In August 1944, at the age of seventy-two, Mrs. Westermann was airlifted to France by paratroopers.
She had been invited by her friend and fellow archaeologist, Dr. Henri Leclerc, who served as a French officer during World War II.
She was one of three women selected for the mission, which was codenamed Operation Rudder.
The three women were flown into France in order to take photographs and make sketches of artifacts that would be removed from France before the Nazis could destroy them.
In addition to the other two women, Mrs. Westermann carried a camera, binoculars, and several sketchbooks.
She was also provided with a gun, but she did not use it during the mission.

human: Colette Rossant, a native of Paris whose childhood in Cairo before and during World War II gave her a global view of cuisine that eventually helped fuel a prominent career in New York as a cookbook author, food critic and food memoirist, died on Thursday at her home in Normandy, France.
She was 91.
llm: Colette Rossant, a food writer and cooking teacher who helped popularize French cuisine in the United States after World War II, died on Saturday at her home in Paris.
She was 91.
Her death was confirmed by her daughter, Marie-Louise Rossant.
A native of Paris, Ms. Rossant moved to the United States as a young woman and worked for many years as an editor and writer for The New York Times.
In 1947, she wrote one of the earliest articles about nouvelle cuisine, which would later become a culinary movement in France.
But Ms. Rossant did not write cookbooks or open restaurants.
Rather, she devoted herself to teaching and writing about French cooking, including how it had changed over the centuries.
She was known for her extensive knowledge of French history and culture.

human: Salman Rushdie, the acclaimed novelist and free speech advocate who was viciously attacked at a public event last year, will write a memoir about the experience, his publisher, Penguin Random House, announced Wednesday.
llm: Salman Rushdie, the author of The Satanic Verses, will write a memoir about his life since being stabbed in the neck and torso at an event last month.
"I want to remember what happened," he told the New York Times.
"And I want to try to make sense of it."

human: Dorothy Hoffner, born in 1918, had survived both the Spanish flu and Covid pandemics, as well as her first skydiving attempt at age 100.
llm: Dorothy Hoffner, born in 1908, is the world's oldest skydiver.

The video also shows her jumping from a plane and landing safely on the ground.

human: For over a year, we’ve been rooting through jazz history five minutes at a time.
We’ve covered favorites by Ornette Coleman, Mary Lou Williams, New Orleans’s jazz greats and many others.

Now let’s turn our attention to a vocalist who epitomized — but couldn’t be contained by — jazz: Sarah Vaughan, “The Divine One,” owner of perhaps the most impressive vocal instrument in recorded history.
llm: For over a decade, this was the best-selling jazz album on iTunes.
It's hard to disagree: Vaughan is one of the great singers of all time, and her voice has never sounded more warm, mellow or human than it does here.
And she's joined by some of the finest musicians in jazz history, including Clifford Brown, John Coltrane, Kenny Burrell, Wynton Kelly and Jimmy Cobb.
The music is classic, but the sound quality is state of the art; remastered from original analog tapes, it will make you feel as if you're sitting right next to Ms. Vaughan. --
Jeff Tamarkin, 10/24/12, PopMatters

human: Certain kinds of surprises are de rigueur in television.
The shock of when a character unexpectedly dies, for instance.
It’s jolting, sure, but it’s nothing too out of the ordinary.
Television writers do it all the time.
llm: Certain kinds of TV shows have a tendency to get more interesting when they're about to end.

The final season of Game of Thrones is the most obvious recent example, but the same thing happened on Westworld last year, and it's happening now on The Curse, which has wrapped up its first season with a two-hour finale that features some very big developments for the characters and the plot.

human: How do you sift through Mexico City’s roughly 57,000 places to eat — more than twice as many as there are in New York City — and choose the most essential dishes?
“In a city like Mexico City, how do you narrow it down?
It’s insane.

The exercise is absurd to begin with,” says Gabriela Cámara, the chef and owner of Contramar and three other restaurants in the Mexican capital, at the outset of the video conversation I’d arranged to do just that: identify the specific meals or bites (or drinks) that best represent the metropolis’s formidable food scene right now.

Nonetheless, Cámara was up for the challenge, as were the four other panelists I’d convened, all of whom live in Mexico City either year-round or part time: Ana Dolores, the chef and owner of Esquina Común restaurant in the Condesa neighborhood; Anais Martinez, who founded the Curious Mexican, a street-food tour company, and recently opened Manada, an all-Mexican cocktail and natural wine bar in Narvarte; the food writer Alonso Ruvalcaba, the author of the guide “24 Horas de Comida en la Ciudad de México” (2018); and Carla Valdivia Nakatani, T Magazine’s art director, who splits her time between Manhattan and Mexico City, where she co-owns a boutique in Roma.

Before we met as a group, I’d asked each participant to nominate around 10 dishes, including a sweet and a drink, from 10 different spots, ranging from fine-dining restaurants to street carts and market stalls.

Then we spent two hours and several subsequent emails and phone calls debating our choices, trying to whittle down the 50-plus nominations to 25 in order to produce a list like those in the ongoing T 25 series devoted to food in Paris and in New York.
llm: How do you get around?

human: The cicadas are coming — and if you’re in the Midwest or the Southeast, they will be more plentiful than ever.
Or at least since the Louisiana Purchase.
llm: The cicadas are back!
The broods of periodical cicadas, also known as the 17-year locusts, are expected to emerge in the eastern and midwestern United States this spring.
The last time these insects emerged was in 2004.
This year is an especially big one for them because it's a so-called supercolony year.
That means more than one brood will be active at the same time.
That hasn't happened since 1803.
The cicadas are actually good news for our planet.
They are a vital part of the ecosystem.
They provide food for other animals and plants and help pollinate flowers.
(New York Times)

human: See results for key races in the Nov. 7 general election.

human: In the 1970s, soft-shell clams started mysteriously dying off in Maine and the Chesapeake Bay.

llm: In the 1970s, a mysterious cancer began to spread through mussels and other bivalves in the Pacific Northwest.

human: A few years after the Society for the Protection of New Hampshire Forests started a Christmas tree farm, Nigel Manley, who oversaw the operations, began noticing some interesting developments among the rows of fragrant balsam and Fraser firs lining the land.
llm: A few years ago, my family and I were driving through the mountains of Colorado on our way to visit some friends.
We had to stop for a while because we got stuck in traffic due to an accident.
As we waited for things to get moving again, we noticed that there was a huge pile of Christmas trees at the side of the road.
We wondered why they were there, but it wasn't until later that we learned what had happened.
Apparently, someone had driven into a tree farm and knocked down several trees.
The owners decided to donate them to the highway department so they could be used as part of their landscaping project.

human: The terms of the private loan were as generous as they were clear: With no money down, Justice Clarence Thomas could borrow more than a quarter of a million dollars from a wealthy friend to buy a 40-foot luxury motor coach, making annual interest-only payments for five years.

llm: The terms of the loan were not disclosed in Justice Thomas' financial disclosure forms from 1986 to 1994.

human: The rapid rise of Oliver Anthony’s “Rich Men North of Richmond,” plus the playful pop of the TikTok star Rae.

llm: The rapid rise of TikTok star Addison Rae has been impressive.

human: “The Sweet East,” a shape-shifting satire about modern American subcultures, is a curious — occasionally delightful — object.

human: A lot happened in the early 1990s:

llm: A lot happened in the world in 1993, which was also a turning point for two TV shows that are now returning to the airwaves: 'The Wire' and 'The Last of Us.'

human: When Indiana officials created a new industrial park to lure huge microchip firms to the state, they picked a nearly 10,000-acre site close to a booming metropolis, a major airport and a university research center.
llm: When Indiana officials unveiled a plan last month to pump more than 50 million gallons of groundwater each day from southeastern Indiana into a new microchip plant near Indianapolis, they said it would be no problem.
The water comes from an aquifer that has never been used before and is replenished by rainfall and runoff, according to the state's water commissioner.
“There's plenty of water there," he said in December.

But opponents of the $10 billion Intel project say the state's assessment of how much water is in the aquifer is flawed, based on outdated models, and that draining the aquifer could harm nearby streams and springs.

human: Margaret Newcomb, 69, a retired French teacher, is desperately trying to protect her retirement savings by caring for her 82-year-old husband, who has severe dementia, at home in Seattle.
She used to fear his disease-induced paranoia, but now he’s so frail and confused that he wanders away with no idea of how to find his way home.
He gets lost so often that she attaches a tag to his shoelace with her phone number.
llm: Margaret Newcomb, 69, has been living in a small assisted-living apartment in the Bronx since 2014.
Her daughter, Linda DePasquale, visits her once or twice a week.

human: On Dec. 11, NASA engineers anxiously gathered at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., to view a cat video, wondering if it would be in the pristine high definition for which they had hoped.

human: And just like that, Ron DeSantis’s quest for the presidency is kaput.

It wasn’t a terrible performance, especially under the circumstances.
But watching Mr. DeSantis’s now-famous awkward smile and listening to his unnatural cadence, it was hard not to think:
Yeah.
I can see why this guy’s candidacy is deader than disco.
llm: And just like that, the former governor of Florida was elected to Congress.
Now he's being called a frontrunner for president.

human: Clallam County in Washington State is far from Washington, D.C. — almost as far as you can go without leaving the continental United States.
llm: Clallam County in Washington State has a long tradition of voting for Republican candidates.
But with Democrats holding all three statewide offices, and the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives, it is time to take a look at what has been happening over the past 40 years.
There have been 21 general elections since 1980, and every single one of them have been won by the Republican Party.
The GOP's last loss was in 1976 when Democrat Jimmy Carter was elected President of the United States.

human: After weeks of anticipation, a volcanic eruption in Iceland’s most populated area sent lava spewing into the night sky late Monday and pushed the authorities into action mode Tuesday.

llm: After weeks of rumbling, the volcano Bardarbunga in Iceland began erupting early Sunday morning.

human: “When I was maybe 3 years old or so, I was given a gold bracelet with dragons on it from my grandmother,” Diane Neuville said on a video call from Versailles, France, where she lives and works.

It’s symbolic, like a message of love from the family.”
llm: “When I was young, I wanted to be a jewelry designer.
But at 13, my family moved from New York to Los Angeles and, as a result, I lost contact with the people who inspired me and made it possible.”
(Source: https://www.jckonline.com/article/the-story-of-a-new-york-jeweler-who-is-designing-for-the-younger-set/)

human: At age 80, Byron Wien compiled “20 Life Lessons” from a long career as a Wall Street soothsayer.
“Never retire” was No. 20.
“If you work forever, you can live forever,’’ he explained.
“I know there is an abundance of biological evidence against this theory, but I’m going with it anyway.”
llm: At age 80, Byron Wien wrote a book called "Unexpected Returns: Understanding Secular Stock Market Cycles".
The title was inspired by his experience with the unexpected.
His career started in 1957 when he began working as an analyst for a hedge fund.
This was before the era of computers, and he had to keep track of the numbers by hand.
He then moved on to become chief technical strategist at Morgan Stanley, where he worked until his retirement in 2009.
During his time there, he developed a theory about how stocks move in cycles that are not based on economic factors but instead depend on investor psychology.
This led him to predict the market's next move.
His predictions were usually correct.

human: Even in the Golden Age of musical theater, shows so commonly died after intermission that critics came up with a name for the disease.

Yet all those second act symptoms arose from the same underlying condition: first act ambitions.
llm: Even in the first half of Season 16, "Hell's Kitchen" is still a lot of fun.
The new judges — including Alicia Keys, who is actually a pretty good judge and mentor — have been able to bring something fresh to the show without losing what makes it work.

human: Inside the “blueberry muffin” conference room, the walls are, naturally, painted blue.

human: In a perfect world, you’d always be able to serve your Thanksgiving turkey directly after its sojourn in the oven.

llm: In a perfect world, we'd all have the time and energy to make homemade bread stuffing for our turkey every year.
In reality, though, most of us don't have that kind of time or energy — especially if you're prepping everything yourself.
So if you're looking for an easy way to save time on your big meal this year, consider making a brined turkey.
You can start the process days ahead of time, and it's so simple: Just cover your bird in a mixture of water, salt, and sugar, then refrigerate.
The result is a juicy, flavorful turkey with very little effort required.

human: When you’re choosing curtains for a room, there are so many things to consider.
Jake Arnold, an interior designer in Los Angeles, walks us through it.
llm: When you’re choosing drapes for your home, the number one thing you need to consider is how much light you want to let in.
If you choose a sheer fabric like silk or cotton, you can still get the privacy that comes with drapes while still letting in natural sunlight.
On the other hand, if you want to block out all of the sun, you might want to opt for a heavier fabric like velvet.
You should also consider the color and pattern of your drapes.
If you want them to blend in with the rest of your décor, go with a solid color.
But if you want them to stand out, go with a bold pattern.

human: It started with a postcard-perfect snapshot.

human: The word ordeal has appeared in 291 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 31 in “I Was Trying to Build My Son’s Resilience, Not Scar Him for Life” by Erik Vance:
llm: The word ordeal has its origins in the Old English orðaðel, which was made up of two words.
The first element, orð-, means “judgment.”
The second, -dael, means “part” or “portion.”
Thus, orðaðel meant “judgment portion,” and referred to a particular type of trial.

human: In Weirton, W.Va., in the heart of coal country, a company started by MIT scientists plans to build a plant that will produce a metal and alloy critical for clean energy, fuel cells and cleaner steel.
llm: In Weirton, W.Va., where a steel mill closed in 2015, the new owner plans to spend $35 million to convert it into a factory that would make insulation from recycled glass.

llm: When is walking just a walk, and when does it become an adventure?
When you have the right map, of course!
Join us for a virtual stroll around some of the best circular walks in London.
These short, easy walks are suitable for all ages, and are a great way to explore parts of the city that you may not have visited before.
You'll learn about different types of Londoners, from celebrities to ordinary people who have made their mark on history, as well as famous places like Hyde Park, Trafalgar Square and the Thames.
The routes are designed so that they can be easily navigated by anyone with reasonable mobility - there are no steep hills or stairs to climb!
